original: Dīgha Nikāya 2
analyzed: dīgha nikāya
translated: Long Discourses

original: Sāmaññaphalasutta
analyzed: sāmañña phala sutta
translated: The Fruits of the Ascetic Life

original: 1. Rājāmaccakathā
analyzed: rājā amat cakathā
translated: The Discussion with the King’s Men

original: Evaṁ me sutaṁ—
analyzed: evam me suta
translated: Thus have I heard.

original: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā rājagahe viharati jīvakassa komārabhaccassa ambavane mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṁ aḍḍhateḷasehi bhikkhusatehi.🔽Tena kho pana samayena rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tadahuposathe pannarase
analyzed: ekam samayam bhagavā rājagahe viharati jīvakassa komārabhaccassa ambavane mahatā bhikkhu saṅghena saddhim aḍḍhateḷasehi bhikkhu satehi  tena kho pana samayena rājā māgadhaḥ ajātasattu vedehiputto tadahuposathe pannarase
translated: Once the Buddha was staying at Rājagaha in Jīvaka Komārabhacca’s Mango Grove, together with a large Saṅgha of twelve-hundred and fifty monks.🔽On that occasion, on the Uposatha day of the fifteenth, the full-moon night of the Komudi full moon,

original: komudiyā cātumāsiniyā puṇṇāya puṇṇamāya rattiyā rājāmaccaparivuto uparipāsādavaragato nisinno hoti.
analyzed: komudiyā cātumāsiniyā puṇṇāya puṇṇamāya rattiyā rājā amacca parivutaḥ upari pāsāda vara gataḥ nisinnaḥ hoti
translated: King Ajātasattu of Magadha, the son of the Videhi lady, was sitting in the upper hall surrounded by his ministers.

original: Atha kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tadahuposathe udānaṁ udānesi:
analyzed: atha kho rājā māgadhaḥ ajātasattu vedehi putto tadahu posathe udānam udānesi
translated: Then, on that Uposatha day, King Ajātasattu of Magadha uttered this verse of elation:

original: “ramaṇīyā vata bho dosinā ratti, abhirūpā vata bho dosinā ratti, dassanīyā vata bho dosinā ratti, pāsādikā vata bho dosinā ratti, lakkhaññā vata bho dosinā ratti.
analyzed: ramaṇīyā vata bho dosinā ratti abhirūpā vata bho dosinā ratti dassanīyā vata bho dosinā ratti pāsādikā vata bho dosinā ratti lakkhaññā vata bho dosinā ratti
translated: “How delightful is this moonlit night! How beautiful, how lovely, how inspiring, how auspicious!

original: Kaṁ nu khvajja samaṇaṁ vā brāhmaṇaṁ vā payirupāseyyāma, yaṁ no payirupāsato cittaṁ pasīdeyyā”ti?🔽Evaṁ vutte, aññataro rājāmacco rājānaṁ māgadhaṁ ajātasattuṁ vedehiputtaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: kam nu khvajja samaṇam vā brāhmaṇam vā payis upāseyyāma yam no payis upāsataḥ cittam pasīdeyya iti  evam vutte aññataraḥ rājā amaccaḥ rājānam māgadham ajātasattum vedehi puttam etat avoca
translated: “Whom should we visit today, a contemplative or a brahmin, by visiting whom our mind might be gladdened?”

original: “ayaṁ, deva, pūraṇo kassapo saṅghī ceva gaṇī ca gaṇācariyo ca ñāto yasassī titthakaro sādhusammato bahujanassa rattaññū cirapabbajito addhagato vayoanuppatto.
analyzed: deva pūraṇaḥ kassapaḥ saṅghī ca iva gaṇī ca gaṇa ācariyo ca ñātaḥ yasassī titthakaro sādhu sammataḥ bahu janassa rattaññū cira pabbajitaḥ addha gataḥ vayaḥ anuppatto
translated: When this was said, a certain advisor to the king said to him, “Your Majesty, there is Pūraṇa Kassapa, the leader of a community, the leader of a group, the teacher of a group, the well-known & famous brahmin spiritual teacher regarded by many as a saint.

original: Taṁ devo pūraṇaṁ kassapaṁ payirupāsatu.
analyzed: tam devaḥ pūraṇam kassapam payis upāsatu
translated: Your Majesty should visit Pūraṇa Kassapa.

original: Appeva nāma devassa pūraṇaṁ kassapaṁ payirupāsato cittaṁ pasīdeyyā”ti.
analyzed: appā iva nāma devassa pūraṇam kassapam payirupāsato cittam pasīdeyya ati
translated: Perhaps, by visiting Pūraṇa Kassapa, your mind might be gladdened.”

original: Evaṁ vutte, rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tuṇhī ahosi.
analyzed: evam vutte rājā māgadhaḥ ajātasattu vedehi putto tuṇhī ahosi
translated: When this was said, King Ajātasattu of Magadha remained silent.

original: Aññataropi kho rājāmacco rājānaṁ māgadhaṁ ajātasattuṁ vedehiputtaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: aññataraḥ api kho rājā amaccaḥ rājānam māgadham ajātasattum vedehiputtam etat avoca
translated: Another advisor to the king said to him, “Your Majesty, there is Makkhali Gosāla, the leader of a community, the leader of a group, the teacher of a group, the well-known & famous brahmin spiritual teacher regarded by many as a saint.

original: “ayaṁ, deva, makkhali gosālo saṅghī ceva gaṇī ca gaṇācariyo ca ñāto yasassī titthakaro sādhusammato bahujanassa rattaññū cirapabbajito addhagato vayoanuppatto.
analyzed: deva makkhali gosālo saṅghī ca iva gaṇī ca gaṇa ācariyo ca ñātaḥ yasassī titthakaro sādhu sammataḥ bahu janassa rattaññū cira pabbajitaḥ addha gataḥ vayaḥ anuppatto
translated: “Your Majesty, Makkhali Gosāla is the head of an order, the head of a group, the teacher of a group, the well-known and famous founder of a sect regarded by many as a saint.

original: Taṁ devo makkhaliṁ gosālaṁ payirupāsatu.
analyzed: tam devaḥ makkhalim gosālam payiḥ upāsatu
translated: May Your Majesty visit Makkhali Gosāla.

original: Appeva nāma devassa makkhaliṁ gosālaṁ payirupāsato cittaṁ pasīdeyyā”ti.
analyzed: appā iva nāma devassa makkhalim gosālam payirupāsato cittam pasīdeyya ati
translated: Perhaps Your Majesty’s mind will be uplifted on seeing him.”

original: Evaṁ vutte, rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tuṇhī ahosi.
analyzed: evam vutte rājā māgadhaḥ ajātasattu vedehi putto tuṇhī ahosi
translated: When this was said, King Ajatasattu remained silent.

original: Aññataropi kho rājāmacco rājānaṁ māgadhaṁ ajātasattuṁ vedehiputtaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: aññataraḥ api kho rājā amaccaḥ rājānam māgadham ajātasattum vedehiputtam etat avoca
translated: Another minister said to him:

original: “ayaṁ, deva, ajito kesakambalo saṅghī ceva gaṇī ca gaṇācariyo ca ñāto yasassī titthakaro sādhusammato bahujanassa rattaññū cirapabbajito addhagato vayoanuppatto.
analyzed: deva ajitaḥ kesakambalo saṅghī ca iva gaṇī ca gaṇa ācariyo ca ñātaḥ yasassī titthakaro sādhu sammataḥ bahu janassa rattaññū cira pabbajitaḥ addha gataḥ vayaḥ anuppatto
translated: “Your Majesty, Ajita Kesakambala is the head of an order, the head of a group, the teacher of a group, the well-known and famous founder of a sect regarded by many as a saint.

original: Taṁ devo ajitaṁ kesakambalaṁ payirupāsatu.
analyzed: tam devaḥ ajitam kesa kambalam payiḥ upāsatu
translated: May Your Majesty visit Ajita Kesakambala.

original: Appeva nāma devassa ajitaṁ kesakambalaṁ payirupāsato cittaṁ pasīdeyyā”ti.
analyzed: appā iva nāma devassa ajitam kesakambalam payirupāsato cittam pasīdeyya ati
translated: Perhaps Your Majesty’s mind will be uplifted on seeing him.”

original: Evaṁ vutte, rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tuṇhī ahosi.
analyzed: evam vutte rājā māgadhaḥ ajātasattu vedehi putto tuṇhī ahosi
translated: When this was said, King Ajatasattu of Magadha remained silent.

original: Aññataropi kho rājāmacco rājānaṁ māgadhaṁ ajātasattuṁ vedehiputtaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: aññataraḥ api kho rājā amaccaḥ rājānam māgadham ajātasattum vedehiputtam etat avoca
translated: Then another minister said to him:

original: “ayaṁ, deva, pakudho kaccāyano saṅghī ceva gaṇī ca gaṇācariyo ca ñāto yasassī titthakaro sādhusammato bahujanassa rattaññū cirapabbajito addhagato vayoanuppatto.
analyzed: deva pakudho kaccāyano saṅghī ca iva gaṇī ca gaṇa ācariyo ca ñātaḥ yasassī tittha karo sādhu sammataḥ bahu janassa rattaññū cira pabbajitaḥ addha gataḥ vayaḥ anuppatto
translated: “Sire, there is also Pakudha Kaccāyana, who has many hundreds of disciples and teachers disciples and is well-known and famous, and has been a spiritual teacher for many years.

original: Taṁ devo pakudhaṁ kaccāyanaṁ payirupāsatu.
analyzed: tam devaḥ pakudham kaccāyanam payiḥ upāsatu
translated: Sire, please visit Pakudha Kaccāyana.

original: Appeva nāma devassa pakudhaṁ kaccāyanaṁ payirupāsato cittaṁ pasīdeyyā”ti.
analyzed: appā iva nāma devassa pakudham kaccāyanam payirupāsato cittam pasīdeyya ati
translated: Perhaps your mind might be satisfied when you talk with him.”

original: Evaṁ vutte, rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tuṇhī ahosi.
analyzed: evam vutte rājā māgadhaḥ ajātasattu vedehi putto tuṇhī ahosi
translated: When this was said, King Ajatasattu remained silent.

original: Aññataropi kho rājāmacco rājānaṁ māgadhaṁ ajātasattuṁ vedehiputtaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: aññataraḥ api kho rājā amaccaḥ rājānam māgadham ajātasattum vedehiputtam etat avoca
translated: Then another minister said to him:

original: “ayaṁ, deva, sañcayo belaṭṭhaputto saṅghī ceva gaṇī ca gaṇācariyo ca ñāto yasassī titthakaro sādhusammato bahujanassa rattaññū cirapabbajito addhagato vayoanuppatto.🔽Taṁ devo sañcayaṁ belaṭṭhaputtaṁ payirupāsatu.
analyzed: deva sañcayaḥ belaṭṭha putto saṅghī ca iva gaṇī ca gaṇa ācariyo ca ñātaḥ yasassī titthakaro sādhu sammataḥ bahu janassa rattaññū cira pabbajitaḥ addha gataḥ vayaḥ anuppatto  tam devaḥ sañcayam belaṭṭha puttam payis upāsatu
translated: ‘Your Majesty, Sañjaya Belaṭṭhiputta is the head of an order, the head of a group, the teacher of a group, the well-known and famous founder of a sect regarded by many as a saint.🔽Your Majesty should visit Sañjaya Belaṭṭhiputta.

original: Appeva nāma devassa sañcayaṁ belaṭṭhaputtaṁ payirupāsato cittaṁ pasīdeyyā”ti.
analyzed: appā iva nāma devassa sañcayam belaṭṭha puttam payirupāsato cittam pasīdeyya ati
translated: Perhaps, after visiting him, Your Majesty’s mind will be uplifted.’

original: Evaṁ vutte, rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tuṇhī ahosi.
analyzed: evam vutte rājā māgadhaḥ ajātasattu vedehi putto tuṇhī ahosi
translated: But the King of Magadha, Ajatasattu, son of the Videhi queen, remained silent.

original: Aññataropi kho rājāmacco rājānaṁ māgadhaṁ ajātasattuṁ vedehiputtaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: aññataraḥ api kho rājā amaccaḥ rājānam māgadham ajātasattum vedehiputtam etat avoca
translated: Another minister said to him:

original: “ayaṁ, deva, nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto saṅghī ceva gaṇī ca gaṇācariyo ca ñāto yasassī titthakaro sādhusammato bahujanassa rattaññū cirapabbajito addhagato vayoanuppatto.
analyzed: deva nigaṇṭhaḥ nāṭa putto saṅghī ca iva gaṇī ca gaṇa ācariyo ca ñātaḥ yasassī titthakaro sādhu sammataḥ bahu janassa rattaññū cira pabbajitaḥ addha gataḥ vayaḥ anuppatto
translated: ‘Your Majesty, the Nigaṇṭha Nāṭaputta is the head of an order, the head of a group, the teacher of a group, the well-known and famous founder of a sect regarded by many as a saint.

original: Taṁ devo nigaṇṭhaṁ nāṭaputtaṁ payirupāsatu.
analyzed: tam devaḥ nigaṇṭham nāṭa puttam payis upāsatu
translated: Your Majesty should visit the Nigaṇṭha Nāṭaputta.

original: Appeva nāma devassa nigaṇṭhaṁ nāṭaputtaṁ payirupāsato cittaṁ pasīdeyyā”ti.
analyzed: appā iva nāma devassa nigaṇṭham nāṭa puttam payirupāsato cittam pasīdeyya ati
translated: Perhaps your mind will be uplifted by visiting the Nigaṇṭha Nāṭaputta.”

original: Evaṁ vutte, rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tuṇhī ahosi.
analyzed: evam vutte rājā māgadhaḥ ajātasattu vedehi putto tuṇhī ahosi
translated: When this was said, King Ajātasattu of Magadha remained silent.

original: 2. Komārabhaccajīvakakathā
analyzed: komāra bhaccajīvaka kathā
translated: The Discussion with Jīvaka Komārabhacca

original: Tena kho pana samayena jīvako komārabhacco rañño māgadhassa ajātasattussa vedehiputtassa avidūre tuṇhībhūto nisinno hoti.
analyzed: tena kho pana samayena jīvakaḥ komārabhaccaḥ raññaḥ māgadhassa ajātasattussa vedehiputtassa avidūre tuṇhībhūtaḥ nisinnaḥ hoti
translated: Now on that occasion Jīvaka Komārabhacca was sitting not far from King Ajātasattu of Magadha.

original: Atha kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto jīvakaṁ komārabhaccaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha kho rājā māgadhaḥ ajātasattu vedehiputto jīvakam komārabhaccam etat avoca
translated: Then King Ajātasattu of Magadha addressed Jīvaka Komārabhacca, saying:

original: “tvaṁ pana, samma jīvaka, kiṁ tuṇhī”ti?
analyzed: tvam pana samma jīvaka kim tuṇhī iti
translated: “But, dear Jīvaka, why are you silent?”

original: “Ayaṁ, deva, bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho amhākaṁ ambavane viharati mahatā bhikkhusaṅghena saddhiṁ aḍḍhateḷasehi bhikkhusatehi.
analyzed: deva bhagavā araham sammāsambuddhaḥ amhākam ambavane viharati mahatā bhikkhu saṅghena saddhim aḍḍhateḷasehi bhikkhu satehi
translated: “Your majesty, the Blessed One, accomplished and fully enlightened, is staying in my mango grove together with a large community of bhikkhus, with twelve hundred and fifty bhikkhus.

original: Taṁ kho pana bhagavantaṁ evaṁ kalyāṇo kittisaddo abbhuggato:
analyzed: tam khaḥ pana bhagavantam evam kalyāṇaḥ kitti saddaḥ abbhuggataḥ
translated: And of that Blessed One, accomplished and fully enlightened, a good report has been spread in this way:

original: ‘itipi so bhagavā arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho bhagavā’ti.
analyzed: iti pi saḥ bhagavā araham sammāsambuddhaḥ vijjā caraṇa sampanno sugataḥ loka vidū anuttaraḥ purisa damma sārathi satthā deva manussānam buddhaḥ bhagavā ati
translated: ‘The Blessed Lord is accomplished, fully enlightened, perfect in true knowledge and conduct, sublime, knower of worlds, incomparable leader of persons to be tamed, teacher of gods and humans, enlightened, blessed.’

original: Taṁ devo bhagavantaṁ payirupāsatu.
analyzed: tam devaḥ bhagavantam payiḥ upāsatu
translated: Let your majesty go to visit the Lord.

original: Appeva nāma devassa bhagavantaṁ payirupāsato cittaṁ pasīdeyyā”ti.
analyzed: appā iva nāma devassa bhagavantam payirupāsato cittam pasīdeyya ati
translated: Perhaps your majesty’s mind will be uplifted by seeing him.”

original: “Tena hi, samma jīvaka, hatthiyānāni kappāpehī”ti.🔽“Evaṁ, devā”ti kho jīvako komārabhacco rañño māgadhassa ajātasattussa vedehiputtassa
analyzed: tena hi samma jīvaka hatthi yānāni kappa apehi iti  eva deva ati kho jīvakaḥ komārabhaccaḥ raññaḥ māgadhassa ajātasattussa vedehi puttassa
translated: “Well then, Jivaka, get the carriages ready.”

original: paṭissuṇitvā pañcamattāni hatthinikāsatāni kappāpetvā rañño ca ārohaṇīyaṁ nāgaṁ,
analyzed: paṭissuṇitvā pañca mattāni hatthi nikā satāni kappāpetvā raññaḥ ca ārohaṇīyam nāga
translated: “Yes, sire,” he replied, and after getting ready five hundred carriages, and a carriage for the king himself,

original: rañño māgadhassa ajātasattussa vedehiputtassa paṭivedesi:
analyzed: raññaḥ māgadhassa ajātasattussa vedehiputtassa paṭivedesi
translated: he reported to King Ajatasattu:

original: “kappitāni kho te, deva, hatthiyānāni,
analyzed: kappitāni kho te deva hatthi yānāni
translated: “Sire, the carriages are ready,

original: yassadāni kālaṁ maññasī”ti.
analyzed: yaḥ sadāni kālam maññasi iti
translated: and now you may do as you think fit.”

original: Atha kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto pañcasu hatthinikāsatesu paccekā itthiyo
analyzed: atha kho rājā māgadhaḥ ajātasattu vedehi putto pañcasu hatthi nikāsatesu paccekāḥ itthiyaḥ
translated: Then King Ajatasattu had himself carried to the Gabled Hall,

original: āropetvā ārohaṇīyaṁ nāgaṁ abhiruhitvā ukkāsu dhāriyamānāsu rājagahamhā niyyāsi mahaccarājānubhāvena,
analyzed: āropetvā ārohaṇīyam nāgam abhiruhitvā ukkāsu dhāriyamānāsu mahacca rāja anubhāvena
translated: He mounted the elephant, and with torches being carried in front of him, he left Rājagaha with great royal majesty and splendor

original: yena jīvakassa komārabhaccassa ambavanaṁ tena pāyāsi.
analyzed: yena jīvakassa komārabhaccassa ambavanam tena pāyāsi
translated: and went to Jīvaka Komārabhacca’s mango grove.

original: Atha kho rañño māgadhassa ajātasattussa vedehiputtassa avidūre ambavanassa ahudeva bhayaṁ, ahu chambhitattaṁ, ahu lomahaṁso.
analyzed: atha kho raññaḥ māgadhassa ajātasattussa vedehi puttassa avidūre ambavanassa ahudeva ahu chambhitatta ahu
translated: Then, not far from the mango grove, King Ajātasattu became frightened, terrified, and his hair stood on end.

original: Atha kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto bhīto saṁviggo lomahaṭṭhajāto jīvakaṁ komārabhaccaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha kho rājā māgadhaḥ ajātasattu vedehi puttaḥ bhītaḥ sa viggaḥ loma haṭṭha jātaḥ jīvakam komārabhaccam etat avoca
translated: He said to Jīvaka Komārabhacca,

original: “kacci maṁ, samma jīvaka, na vañcesi?🔽Kacci maṁ, samma jīvaka, na palambhesi?
analyzed: kacci ma samma jīvaka na vañcesi  kacci ma samma jīvaka na palambhesi
translated: “Jīvaka, are you not deceiving me?🔽Are you not cheating me?

original: Kacci maṁ, samma jīvaka, na paccatthikānaṁ desi?
analyzed: kacci ma samma jīvaka na paccatthikānam desi
translated: Are you not handing me over to my enemies?

original: Kathañhi nāma tāva mahato bhikkhusaṅghassa aḍḍhateḷasānaṁ bhikkhusatānaṁ neva khipitasaddo bhavissati, na ukkāsitasaddo na nigghoso”ti.
analyzed: katham hi nāma tāva mahataḥ bhikkhu saṅghassa aḍḍhateḷasānam bhikkhu satānam na iva khipita saddaḥ bhavissati na ukkāsita saddaḥ na nigghosaḥ ti
translated: How is it that there is no sound of a large Saṅgha of a thousand monks, no sound of their coughing or clearing their throats?”

original: “Mā bhāyi, mahārāja, mā bhāyi, mahārāja.
analyzed: mā bhāyi mahā rāja mā bhāyi mahā rāja
translated: “Don’t be afraid, great king. Don’t be afraid.

original: Na taṁ, deva, vañcemi;🔽na taṁ, deva, palambhāmi;
analyzed: na ta deva vañcemi  na ta deva palambhāmi
translated: I’m not deceiving you, great king.🔽I’m not betraying you.

original: na taṁ, deva, paccatthikānaṁ demi.
analyzed: na ta deva paccatthikānam demi
translated: I’m not handing you over to your enemies.

original: Abhikkama, mahārāja, abhikkama, mahārāja, ete maṇḍalamāḷe dīpā jhāyantī”ti.
analyzed: abhikkama mahā rāja abhikkama mahā rāja ete maṇḍalamāḷe dīpāḥ jhāyanti iti
translated: Go forward, great king, go forward. The lamps in the pavilion are burning.”

original: 3. Sāmaññaphalapucchā
analyzed: sāmañña phala pucchā
translated: The Questions about the Fruits of the Monastic Life

original: Atha kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto yāvatikā nāgassa bhūmi nāgena gantvā,
analyzed: atha kho rājā māgadhaḥ ajātasattu vedehiputto yāvatikā nāgassa bhūmi nāgena gantvā
translated: Then King Ajātasattu of Magadha, the son of Lady Wisdom, went by elephant as far as the terrain allowed,

original: nāgā paccorohitvā, pattikova yena maṇḍalamāḷassa dvāraṁ tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā
analyzed: nāgā paccorohitvā pattikā uva yena maṇḍalamāḷassa dvāram tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā
translated: dismounted, and then approached the pavilion on foot.

original: jīvakaṁ komārabhaccaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: jīvakam komārabhaccam etat avoca
translated: He said to Jīvaka Komārabhacca,

original: “kahaṁ pana, samma jīvaka, bhagavā”ti?
analyzed: kaham pana samma jīvaka bhagavā ati
translated: “Where is the Buddha, dear Jīvaka?”

original: “Eso, mahārāja, bhagavā;
analyzed: esaḥ mahā rāja bhagavā
translated: “Great king, that’s the Buddha,

original: eso, mahārāja, bhagavā majjhimaṁ thambhaṁ nissāya puratthābhimukho nisinno purakkhato bhikkhusaṅghassā”ti.
analyzed: esaḥ mahā rāja bhagavā majjhimam thambham nissāya purattha abhimukhaḥ nisinnaḥ purakkhataḥ bhikkhu saṅghassa ati
translated: seated with his back to the central pillar, facing east, in front of the Sangha of monks.”

original: Atha kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā ekamantaṁ aṭṭhāsi.
analyzed: atha kho rājā māgadhaḥ ajātasattu vedehi putto yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā ekamantam aṭṭhāsi
translated: Then King Ajātasattu approached the Buddha and stood to one side.

original: Ekamantaṁ ṭhito kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto tuṇhībhūtaṁ tuṇhībhūtaṁ bhikkhusaṅghaṁ anuviloketvā rahadamiva vippasannaṁ udānaṁ udānesi:
analyzed: ekamantam ṭhitaḥ kho rājā māgadhaḥ ajātasattu vedehiputto tuṇhībhūtam tuṇhībhūtam bhikkhu saṅgham anuviloketvā rahadam iva vippasannam udānam udānesi
translated: As he was standing there, he looked over the Saṅgha of monks, who were so very still, and he exclaimed:

original: “iminā me upasamena udayabhaddo kumāro samannāgato hotu, yenetarahi upasamena bhikkhusaṅgho samannāgato”ti.
analyzed: iminā me upasamena udayabhaddaḥ kumāro samannāgataḥ hotu yena itarahi upasamena bhikkhu saṅgho samannāgato ti
translated: “May Prince Udayabhadda be endowed with the same peacefulness as the Saṅgha of monks is endowed with right now.”

original: “Agamā kho tvaṁ, mahārāja, yathāpeman”ti.
analyzed: agama kha u tva mahā rāja yathāpemanti
translated: “Go at your convenience, Great King.”

original: “Piyo me, bhante, udayabhaddo kumāro.
analyzed: piyaḥ me bhante udayabhaddaḥ kumāraḥ
translated: “Venerable Sir, Prince Udayabhadda is dear to me.

original: Iminā me, bhante, upasamena udayabhaddo kumāro samannāgato hotu yenetarahi upasamena bhikkhusaṅgho samannāgato”ti.🔽Atha kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā, bhikkhusaṅghassa añjaliṁ paṇāmetvā, ekamantaṁ nisīdi.
analyzed: iminā me bhante upasamena udayabhaddaḥ kumāro samannāgataḥ hotu yena itarahi upasamena bhikkhu saṅgho samannāgataḥ ti  atha kho rājā māgadhaḥ ajātasattu vedehi puttaḥ bhagavantam abhivādetvā bhikkhu saṅghassa añjalim paṇāmetvā ekamantam nisīdi
translated: May Prince Udayabhadda be endowed with the same peacefulness as the Saṅgha of monks is endowed with right now.”🔽Then King Ajatasattu of Magadha, having bowed down to the Blessed One and having raised his hands palm-to-palm in reverential salutation, sat down to one side.

original: Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: ekamantam nisinnaḥ khalu rājā māgadhaḥ ajātasattu vedehiputto bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: As he was sitting there, he said to the Blessed One:

original: “puccheyyāmahaṁ, bhante, bhagavantaṁ kañcideva desaṁ;
analyzed: puccheyyāmaha bhante bhagavantam kañcid eva desa
translated: “Venerable Sir, I would like to ask the Buddha about a certain point,

original: sace me bhagavā okāsaṁ karoti pañhassa veyyākaraṇāyā”ti.
analyzed: sace me bhagavā okāsam karoti pañhassa veyyākaraṇāya ati
translated: if the Buddha would be so kind as to give me an opportunity to explain my question.”

original: “Puccha, mahārāja, yadākaṅkhasī”ti.
analyzed: puccha mahā rāja yat ākaṅkhasi iti
translated: “Ask, great king. Whatever you wish.”

original: “Yathā nu kho imāni, bhante, puthusippāyatanāni,
analyzed: yathā nu kho imāni bhante puthusippa āyatanāni
translated: “Sir, there are these various crafts,🔽such as elephant-craft,🔽horse-craft,🔽chariot-craft,🔽archery,

original: seyyathidaṁ—hatthārohā assārohā rathikā dhanuggahā celakā calakā piṇḍadāyakā uggā rājaputtā pakkhandino mahānāgā sūrā cammayodhino dāsikaputtā
analyzed: seyyathida hattha ārohā assa ārohā rathikā dhanuggahā celakā calakā piṇḍadāyakā uggāḥ rāja puttā pakkhandinaḥ mahā nāgā sūrā camma yodhinaḥ dāsika puttā
translated: fencing,🔽boxing,🔽wrestling,🔽dice,🔽stick-fighting,

original: āḷārikā kappakā nhāpakā sūdā mālakārā rajakā pesakārā naḷakārā kumbhakārā gaṇakā
analyzed: āḷārikā kappakā nhāpakā sūdāḥ mālakārāḥ rajakāḥ pesakārāḥ naḷakārāḥ kumbhakārāḥ gaṇakāḥ
translated: hand-to-hand combat,🔽and spying,🔽or whatever other crafts there are like these.

original: muddikā, yāni vā panaññānipi evaṅgatāni puthusippāyatanāni, te diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṁ
analyzed: muddikā yāni vā pana aññāni pi evaṅgatāni puthu sippa āyatanāni te diṭṭhe iva dhamme sandiṭṭhika
translated: In this very life, they reap the fruit of their craft,

original: sippaphalaṁ upajīvanti;
analyzed: sippa phalam upajīvanti
translated: and they live on that.🔽They make themselves happy and pleased,🔽and they make their parents,

original: te tena attānaṁ sukhenti pīṇenti, mātāpitaro sukhenti pīṇenti, puttadāraṁ sukhenti
analyzed: te tena attānam sukhenti pīṇenti mātā pitaraḥ sukhenti pīṇenti putta dāram sukhenti
translated: their wives and children,🔽and their friends and colleagues happy and pleased.

original: pīṇenti, mittāmacce sukhenti pīṇenti, samaṇabrāhmaṇesu uddhaggikaṁ dakkhiṇaṁ patiṭṭhapenti
analyzed: pīṇenti mitta amacce sukhenti pīṇenti samaṇa brāhmaṇesu uddhaggikam dakkhiṇam patiṭṭhapenti
translated: they gladden and satisfy their friends and companions, and they establish the highest form of offering to ascetics and brahmins.

original: sovaggikaṁ sukhavipākaṁ saggasaṁvattanikaṁ.
analyzed: sovaggikam sukha vipākam
translated: They make their friends and companions happy and content, and they establish the highest act of worship for ascetics and brahmins.🔽This leads to a good rebirth, to happiness, to a heavenly world.”

original: Sakkā nu kho, bhante, evameva diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ paññapetun”ti?
analyzed: sakkā nu kho bhante evam eva diṭṭhe iva dhamme sandiṭṭhikam sāmañña phalam paññapetunti
translated: “Venerable sir, is it possible to point out a fruit of the contemplative life that is visible here and now?”

original: “Abhijānāsi no tvaṁ, mahārāja, imaṁ pañhaṁ aññe samaṇabrāhmaṇe pucchitā”ti?
analyzed: abhijānāsi no tva mahā rāja imam pañham aññe samaṇa brāhmaṇe pucchitā ati
translated: “Great king, do you recall my asking you about this matter when you went forth into homelessness with the ascetic Gotama?”

original: “Abhijānāmahaṁ, bhante, imaṁ pañhaṁ aññe samaṇabrāhmaṇe pucchitā”ti.
analyzed: abhijānāmaha bhante imam pañham aññe samaṇa brāhmaṇe pucchitā ati
translated: “Yes, venerable sir, I do.”

original: “Yathā kathaṁ pana te, mahārāja, byākariṁsu, sace te agaru bhāsassū”ti.
analyzed: yathā katham pana te mahā rāja byākarisu sace te agaru bhāsassu iti
translated: “Then, great king, if you don’t think it is troublesome for you, I would like to hear your answer to my question.”

original: “Na kho me, bhante, garu, yatthassa bhagavā nisinno, bhagavantarūpo vā”ti.
analyzed: na kho me bhante garu yatthassa bhagavā nisinnaḥ bhagavantarūpaḥ vāti
translated: “Venerable sir, I don’t consider it troublesome to answer a question when the Blessed One is sitting right here.”

original: “Tena hi, mahārāja, bhāsassū”ti.
analyzed: tena hi mahā rāja
translated: “Then, great king, answer it if you like.”

original: 3.1. Pūraṇakassapavāda
analyzed: pūraṇakassapavāda
translated: .. The doctrine of Pūraṇa Kassapa

original: “Ekamidāhaṁ, bhante, samayaṁ yena pūraṇo kassapo tenupasaṅkamiṁ; upasaṅkamitvā pūraṇena kassapena saddhiṁ sammodiṁ.
analyzed: ekam id āha bhante samayam yena pūraṇaḥ kassapo tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā pūraṇena kassapena saddhim sammodi
translated: “On one occasion, venerable sir, I went to Pūraṇa Kassapa and asked him:

original: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁ. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho ahaṁ, bhante, pūraṇaṁ kassapaṁ etadavocaṁ:🔽‘yathā nu kho imāni, bho kassapa, puthusippāyatanāni,
analyzed: sammodanīyam katham sāraṇīyam vītisāretvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnaḥ kho aha bhante pūraṇam kassapam etat avoca  yathā nu kho imāni bho kassapa puthu sippa āyatanāni
translated: and when the greetings and polite conversation were over, I sat down to one side and asked him:

original: seyyathidaṁ—hatthārohā assārohā rathikā dhanuggahā celakā calakā piṇḍadāyakā uggā🔽rājaputtā pakkhandino mahānāgā sūrā cammayodhino dāsikaputtā āḷārikā kappakā nhāpakā
analyzed: seyyathida hattha ārohāḥ assa ārohāḥ rathikāḥ dhanuggahāḥ celakā calakā piṇḍadāyakāḥ uggāḥ  rāja puttā pakkhandinaḥ mahā nāgā sūrā camma yodhinaḥ dāsika puttā āḷārikāḥ kappakāḥ nhāpakā
translated: ‘Master Kassapa, how is it: Are these various kinds of speculative views found in the world arisen because of this or that?🔽That is, the view: “The world and self are eternal” …🔽or the view: “After death a Tathāgata neither exists nor does not exist” ?🔽Or are they arisen in other ways?

original: sūdā mālakārā rajakā pesakārā naḷakārā kumbhakārā gaṇakā muddikā, yāni vā panaññānipi
analyzed: sūdāḥ mālakārāḥ rajakāḥ pesakārāḥ naḷakārāḥ kumbhakārāḥ gaṇakāḥ muddikāḥ yāni vā panaññāni pi
translated: ‘“Master Kassapa, there are these various kinds of speculative views found in the world:🔽That is, the view: “The world and self are eternal” …🔽or the view: “After death a Tathāgata neither exists nor does not exist” .

original: evaṅgatāni puthusippāyatanāni, te diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṁ sippaphalaṁ upajīvanti;
analyzed: evaṅgatāni puthu sippāyatanāni te diṭṭhe iva dhamme sandiṭṭhikam sippa phalam upajīvanti
translated: Are these various kinds of speculative views found in the world arisen because of this or that?

original: te tena attānaṁ sukhenti pīṇenti, mātāpitaro sukhenti pīṇenti, puttadāraṁ sukhenti🔽pīṇenti, mittāmacce sukhenti pīṇenti, samaṇabrāhmaṇesu uddhaggikaṁ dakkhiṇaṁ patiṭṭhapenti
analyzed: te tena attānam sukhenti pīṇenti mātā pitaraḥ sukhenti pīṇenti putta dāram sukhenti 🔽pīṇenti mitta amacce sukhenti pīṇenti samaṇa brāhmaṇesu uddhaggikam dakkhiṇam patiṭṭhapenti
translated: Or are they arisen in other ways? ‘

original: sovaggikaṁ sukhavipākaṁ saggasaṁvattanikaṁ.
analyzed: sovaggikam sukha vipākam
translated: it leads to heaven, and to what is wished for, liked, agreeable and delightful.

original: Sakkā nu kho, bho kassapa, evameva diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ paññapetun’ti?
analyzed: sakkā nu kho bho kassapa evam eva diṭṭhe iva dhamme sandiṭṭhikam sāmañña phalam paññapetunti
translated: Is it possible, Master Kassapa, to point out a fruit of recluseship visible here and now?’

original: Evaṁ vutte, bhante, pūraṇo kassapo maṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: evam vutte bhante pūraṇaḥ kassapaḥ mam etat avoca
translated: When this was said, Pūraṇa replied:

original: ‘karoto kho, mahārāja, kārayato, chindato chedāpayato, pacato pācāpayato socayato,🔽socāpayato, kilamato kilamāpayato, phandato phandāpayato, pāṇamatipātāpayato, adinnaṁ🔽ādiyato, sandhiṁ chindato, nillopaṁ harato, ekāgārikaṁ karoto, paripanthe tiṭṭhato,
analyzed: karotaḥ khalu mahā rāja kārayataḥ chindataḥ chedāpayataḥ pacataḥ pācāpayataḥ socayataḥ  socāpayataḥ kilamataḥ kilamāpayataḥ phandataḥ phandāpayataḥ pāṇam atipātāpayataḥ adinna  ādiyato sandhim chindataḥ nillopam harataḥ ekāgārikam karotaḥ paripanthe tiṭṭhato
translated: ‘Great king, when one makes one cut, makes one pierce, makes one burn, makes one crush, makes one cook, makes one grieve,🔽makes one lament, makes one be distraught, makes one despair, makes one kill, makes one take what is not given,

original: paradāraṁ gacchato, musā bhaṇato, karoto na karīyati pāpaṁ. Khurapariyantena cepi
analyzed: paradāram gacchataḥ musā bhaṇataḥ na pāpa
translated: makes one break into houses, makes one open storehouses, makes one steal in the highways, makes one commit adultery, makes one lie, then evil is not done.

original: cakkena yo imissā pathaviyā pāṇe ekaṁ maṁsakhalaṁ ekaṁ maṁsapuñjaṁ kareyya, natthi
analyzed: cakkena yaḥ imissā pathaviyā pāṇe ekam masa khalam ekam masa puñjam kareyya na atthi
translated: Even if with a razor-edged disk one were to make this earth a single expanse of flesh, a single mass of flesh,

original: tatonidānaṁ pāpaṁ, natthi pāpassa āgamo.
analyzed: tatonidānam pāpa natthi pāpassa āgamaḥ
translated: no evil would thereby accrue, nor would there be any outcome of evil.

original: Dakkhiṇañcepi gaṅgāya tīraṁ gaccheyya hananto ghātento chindanto chedāpento pacanto pācāpento, natthi tatonidānaṁ pāpaṁ, natthi pāpassa āgamo.🔽Uttarañcepi gaṅgāya tīraṁ gaccheyya dadanto dāpento yajanto yajāpento, natthi tatonidānaṁ puññaṁ, natthi puññassa āgamo.
analyzed: dakkhiṇam ce pi gaṅgāya tīram gaccheyya hanantaḥ ghātentaḥ chindantaḥ chedāpentaḥ pacantaḥ pācāpentaḥ natthi tatonidānam pāpa natthi pāpassa āgamaḥ  uttaram ce pi gaṅgāya tīram gaccheyya dadantaḥ dāpentaḥ yajantaḥ yajāpentaḥ natthi tatonidānam puñña natthi puññassa āgamo
translated: If you went along the southern bank of the Ganges killing, making others kill, cutting, making others cut, torturing, making others torture, or going along the northern bank of the Ganges giving, making others give, offering, or making others offer, in neither case would there be any evil or outcome of evil.

original: Dānena damena saṁyamena saccavajjena natthi puññaṁ, natthi puññassa āgamo’ti.
analyzed: dānena damena sayamena saccavajjena natthi puñña natthi puññassa āgamaḥ ti
translated: Giving, self-control, self-restraint, truthfulness, and giving up unwholesome habits—none of these things is wholesome or has a wholesome outcome.’

original: Itthaṁ kho me, bhante, pūraṇo kassapo sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ puṭṭho samāno akiriyaṁ byākāsi.
analyzed: ittham kho me bhante pūraṇaḥ kassapaḥ sandiṭṭhikam sāmañña phalam puṭṭhaḥ samānaḥ akiriyam byākāsi
translated: “When I asked Pūraṇa Kassapa about the fruit of the contemplative life, which is visible here and now, he answered evasively.

original: Seyyathāpi, bhante, ambaṁ vā puṭṭho labujaṁ byākareyya, labujaṁ vā puṭṭho ambaṁ byākareyya;
analyzed: seyyathā api bhante ambam vā puṭṭhaḥ labujam byākareyya labujam vā puṭṭhaḥ ambam byākareyya
translated: Just as if on being asked about a mango he were to describe a breadfruit tree, or on being asked about a breadfruit tree he were to describe a mango:

original: evameva kho me, bhante, pūraṇo kassapo sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ puṭṭho samāno akiriyaṁ byākāsi.
analyzed: evam eva kho me bhante pūraṇaḥ kassapaḥ sandiṭṭhikam sāmañña phalam puṭṭhaḥ samānaḥ akiriyam byākāsi
translated: in the same way, on being asked about the fruit of the contemplative life, which is visible here and now, Pūraṇa Kassapa answered evasively.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhante, etadahosi:
analyzed: tassa mayha bhante
translated: “Then, venerable sir, I thought:

original: ‘kathañhi nāma mādiso samaṇaṁ vā brāhmaṇaṁ vā vijite vasantaṁ apasādetabbaṁ maññeyyā’ti.
analyzed: katham hi nāma mādisaḥ samaṇam vā brāhmaṇam vā vijite vasantam apasādetabbam maññeyya ati
translated: ‘How could I think to disparage a monastic or brahmin living in my realm?’

original: So kho ahaṁ, bhante, pūraṇassa kassapassa bhāsitaṁ neva abhinandiṁ nappaṭikkosiṁ.
analyzed: saḥ kho aha bhante pūraṇassa kassapassa bhāsitam na iva abhinandim na paṭikkosi
translated: So I neither approved nor dismissed Pūraṇa Kassapa’s words.

original: Anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā anattamano, anattamanavācaṁ anicchāretvā, tameva vācaṁ anuggaṇhanto anikkujjanto uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamiṁ.
analyzed: an abhinanditvā ap paṭikkositvā an atta manaḥ an atta mana vācam an icchāretvā tam eva vācam anuggaṇhantaḥ a nikkujjantaḥ uṭṭhāya āsanā pakkami
translated: Neither approving nor dismissing them, and being discontent, I left without delighting in his words.

original: 3.2. Makkhaligosālavāda🔽Ekamidāhaṁ, bhante, samayaṁ yena makkhali gosālo tenupasaṅkamiṁ; upasaṅkamitvā makkhalinā gosālena saddhiṁ sammodiṁ.
analyzed: makkhali gosāla vāda  ekam id āha bhante samayam yena makkhali gosālo tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā makkhalinā gosālena saddhim sammodi
translated: .. Makkhali Gosāla’s view

original: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁ. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho ahaṁ, bhante, makkhaliṁ gosālaṁ etadavocaṁ:
analyzed: sammodanīyam katham sāraṇīyam vītisāretvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnaḥ kho aha bhante makkhalim gosālam etat avoca
translated: On one occasion I went to Makkhali Gosāla, and after exchanging greetings and polite conversation, I sat down to one side. I then said to him:🔽‘What is the cause, what is the reason why some sentient beings are not fully extinguished in the present life?’

original: ‘yathā nu kho imāni, bho gosāla, puthusippāyatanāni …pe…
analyzed: yathā nu kho imāni bho gosāla puthusippa āyatanāni pe
translated: ‘Sir, there are these six directions.

original: sakkā nu kho, bho gosāla, evameva diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ paññapetun’ti?
analyzed: sakkā nu kho bho gosāla evam eva diṭṭhe iva dhamme sandiṭṭhikam sāmañña phalam paññapetunti
translated: Is it possible to point out a fruit of the spiritual life visible here and now?”

original: Evaṁ vutte, bhante, makkhali gosālo maṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: evam vutte bhante makkhali gosālaḥ mam etat avoca
translated: When this was said, Master Gosāla told me:

original: ‘natthi, mahārāja, hetu natthi paccayo sattānaṁ saṅkilesāya, ahetū apaccayā sattā saṅkilissanti.
analyzed: natthi mahā rāja hetu natthi paccayaḥ sattānam saṅkilesāya ahetū apaccayā sattā saṅkilissanti
translated: ‘Great king, there is no cause or condition for the defilement of beings. Beings are defiled without cause or condition.

original: Natthi hetu, natthi paccayo sattānaṁ visuddhiyā,
analyzed: natthi hetu na atthi paccayaḥ sattānam visuddhiyā
translated: There is no cause or condition for the purification of beings.

original: ahetū apaccayā sattā visujjhanti.
analyzed: a hetū a paccayā sattāḥ visujjhanti
translated: Beings are purified without cause or condition.

original: Natthi attakāre, natthi parakāre, natthi purisakāre, natthi balaṁ, natthi vīriyaṁ, natthi purisathāmo, natthi purisaparakkamo.
analyzed: natthi attakāre natthi parakāre natthi purisakāre natthi bala natthi vīriya natthi purisa thāmaḥ natthi purisa parakkamo
translated: There is no self-directed action, no action by another, no action by both, no action by the Almighty, no action by fate, no action by nature, no action by chance, no action by virtue of past kamma.

original: Sabbe sattā sabbe pāṇā sabbe bhūtā sabbe jīvā avasā abalā avīriyā niyatisaṅgatibhāvapariṇatā chasvevābhijātīsu sukhadukkhaṁ paṭisaṁvedenti.
analyzed: sabbe sattā sabbe pāṇā sabbe bhūtā sabbe jīvā avasā abalā a vīriyā niyati saṅgati bhāva pariṇatā chasu eva abhijātīsu sukha dukkham paṭisavedenti
translated: All beings, all living things, all creatures, all souls are without power, without strength, without energy, subject to the odds of change, and in the six great destinations they experience pleasure and pain through the power of previous kamma.

original: Cuddasa kho panimāni yonipamukhasatasahassāni saṭṭhi ca satāni cha ca satāni pañca
analyzed: cuddasa kho panimāni yoni pamukha sata sahassāni saṭṭhi ca satāni cha ca satāni pañca
translated: There are fourteen hundred and forty-six kinds of rebirth in the various orders of beings.

original: ca kammuno satāni pañca ca kammāni tīṇi ca kammāni kamme ca aḍḍhakamme ca dvaṭṭhipaṭipadā🔽dvaṭṭhantarakappā chaḷābhijātiyo aṭṭha purisabhūmiyo ekūnapaññāsa ājīvakasate ekūnapaññāsa🔽paribbājakasate ekūnapaññāsa nāgāvāsasate vīse indriyasate tiṁse nirayasate chattiṁsa
analyzed: ca kammuno satāni pañca ca kammāni tīṇi ca kammāni kamme ca aḍḍha kamme ca dvaṭṭhi paṭipadā  dvaṭṭhantara kappā chaṭṭha abhijātiyaḥ aṭṭha purisabhūmiyaḥ ekūnapaññāsaḥ ājīvaka sate ekūnapaññāsa  paribbājaka sate ekūnapaññāsa nāgāvāsa sate vīse indriya sate tise niraya sate chattisa
translated: and the five hundred kinds of work, and the three kinds of work, and the work and the half-work, and the two-and-thirty ways of behaviour,

original: rajodhātuyo satta saññīgabbhā satta asaññīgabbhā satta nigaṇṭhigabbhā satta devā
analyzed: rajaḥ dhātuyo satta saññī gabbhā satta asaññī gabbhā satta nigaṇṭhi gabbhā satta devā
translated: and the two-and-thirty minor characteristics, and the six classes of men, and the eight stages of human life, and the four hundred and ninety-nine kinds of ascetics, and the four hundred and ninety-nine kinds of wanderers, and the four hundred and ninety-nine kinds of abodes of the Nāgas, and the two thousand and two hundred kinds of sense-desires, and the three thousand and two hundred hells, and the thirty-six elements of dust, and the seven wombs of conscious creatures, and the seven wombs of unconscious creatures, and the seven wombs of Niganthas, and the seven gods,

original: satta mānusā satta pisācā satta sarā satta pavuṭā satta pavuṭasatāni satta papātā
analyzed: satta mānusā satta pisācā satta sarā satta pavuṭā satta pavuṭa satāni satta papātā
translated: and the seven men, and the seven ogres, and the seven lakes, and the seven enclosures, and the seven hundred enclosures, and the seven precipices,

original: satta papātasatāni satta supinā satta supinasatāni cullāsīti mahākappino satasahassāni,
analyzed: satta papāta satāni satta supinā satta supina satāni mahā kappino sata sahassāni
translated: and the seven hundred precipices, and the seven dreams, and the seven hundred dreams, and the eighty-four thousand great aeons,

original: yāni bāle ca paṇḍite ca sandhāvitvā saṁsaritvā dukkhassantaṁ karissanti.
analyzed: yāni bāle ca paṇḍite ca sandhāvitvā sasaritvā dukkhassantam karissanti
translated: during which fools and wise men alike will run and wander, before they make an end of suffering.

original: Tattha natthi “imināhaṁ sīlena vā vatena vā tapena vā brahmacariyena vā aparipakkaṁ vā kammaṁ paripācessāmi, paripakkaṁ vā kammaṁ phussa phussa byantiṁ karissāmī”ti hevaṁ natthi.
analyzed: tattha natthi iminā aham sīlena vā vatena vā tapena vā brahmacariyena vā a paripakkam vā kammam paripācessāmi paripakkam vā kammam phussa phussa byantim karissāmi iti ha evam natthi
translated: There is no such thing as: ‘By this virtue or observance or asceticism or holy life I will bring to completion what has not been completed, or I will perfect what has been completed.’

original: Doṇamite sukhadukkhe pariyantakate saṁsāre, natthi hāyanavaḍḍhane, natthi ukkaṁsāvakaṁse.
analyzed: doṇa mite sukha dukkhe pariyanta kate sa sāre natthi hāyana vaḍḍhane natthi ukkasa avakase
translated: There is a fixed amount of pleasure and pain, and the world stays the same.

original: Seyyathāpi nāma suttaguḷe khitte nibbeṭhiyamānameva paleti;
analyzed: seyyathā api nāma sutta guḷe khitte nibbeṭhiyamānam eva paleti
translated: Just as a waterwheel at a well, with its buckets set on an even level,

original: evameva bāle ca paṇḍite ca sandhāvitvā saṁsaritvā dukkhassantaṁ karissantī’ti.
analyzed: evam eva bāle ca paṇḍite ca sandhāvitvā sasaritvā dukkhassantam karissanti iti
translated: so the fool and the wise one alike will come to an end of suffering.”

original: Itthaṁ kho me, bhante, makkhali gosālo sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ puṭṭho samāno saṁsārasuddhiṁ byākāsi.
analyzed: ittham kho me bhante makkhali gosālaḥ sandiṭṭhikam sāmañña phalam puṭṭhaḥ samānaḥ sa sāra suddhim byākāsi
translated: “When I asked Makkhali Gosala about the fruit of recluseship visible here and now, he explained to me purification by wandering in samsara.

original: Seyyathāpi, bhante, ambaṁ vā puṭṭho labujaṁ byākareyya, labujaṁ vā puṭṭho ambaṁ byākareyya;
analyzed: seyyathā api bhante ambam vā puṭṭhaḥ labujam byākareyya labujam vā puṭṭhaḥ ambam byākareyya
translated: Just as if one asked about a mango would speak about a breadfruit, or asked about a breadfruit would speak about a mango,

original: evameva kho me, bhante, makkhali gosālo sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ puṭṭho samāno saṁsārasuddhiṁ byākāsi.
analyzed: evam eva kho me bhante makkhali gosālaḥ sandiṭṭhikam sāmañña phalam puṭṭhaḥ samānaḥ sa sāra suddhim byākāsi
translated: In the same way, when I asked Makkhali Gosāla about the fruit of the contemplative life, visible here and now, he told me about purification through wandering in saṃsāra.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhante, etadahosi:
analyzed: tassa mayha bhante
translated: I thought,

original: ‘kathañhi nāma mādiso samaṇaṁ vā brāhmaṇaṁ vā vijite vasantaṁ apasādetabbaṁ maññeyyā’ti.
analyzed: katham hi nāma mādisaḥ samaṇam vā brāhmaṇam vā vijite vasantam apasādetabbam maññeyya ati
translated: ‘How can someone like me think to disparage a contemplative or brāhmaṇa who lives in my realm?’

original: So kho ahaṁ, bhante, makkhalissa gosālassa bhāsitaṁ neva abhinandiṁ nappaṭikkosiṁ.
analyzed: saḥ kho aha bhante makkhalissa gosālassa bhāsitam na iva abhinandim na paṭikkosi
translated: So I neither rejoiced in the words of Makkhali Gosāla nor did I reject them.

original: Anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā anattamano, anattamanavācaṁ anicchāretvā, tameva vācaṁ anuggaṇhanto anikkujjanto uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamiṁ.
analyzed: an abhinanditvā ap paṭikkositvā an atta manaḥ an atta mana vācam an icchāretvā tam eva vācam anuggaṇhantaḥ a nikkujjantaḥ uṭṭhāya āsanā pakkami
translated: Neither rejoicing nor rejecting them, and taking neither delight nor aversion to them, I neither approved of them nor fixed my mind on them.

original: 3.3. Ajitakesakambalavāda
analyzed: ajita kesa kambala vāda
translated: .. Ajita Kesakambala’s assertion

original: Ekamidāhaṁ, bhante, samayaṁ yena ajito kesakambalo tenupasaṅkamiṁ; upasaṅkamitvā ajitena kesakambalena saddhiṁ sammodiṁ.
analyzed: ekam id āha bhante samayam yena ajitaḥ kesakambalo tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā ajitena kesakambalena saddhim sammodi
translated: On one occasion I went to Ajita Kesakambala, and after an exchange of friendly greetings and courtesies, I sat down to one side.

original: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁ. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho ahaṁ, bhante, ajitaṁ kesakambalaṁ etadavocaṁ:
analyzed: sammodanīyam katham sāraṇīyam vītisāretvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnaḥ kho aha bhante ajitam kesakambalam etat avoca
translated: and after a friendly exchange of greetings and courtesies, I sat down to one side and asked him:

original: ‘yathā nu kho imāni, bho ajita, puthusippāyatanāni …pe…
analyzed: yathā nu kho imāni bho ajita puthu sippa āyatanāni pe
translated: ‘Master Ajita, how is the following situation to be understood:

original: sakkā nu kho, bho ajita, evameva diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ paññapetun’ti?
analyzed: sakkā nu kho bho ajita evam eva diṭṭhe iva dhamme sandiṭṭhikam sāmañña phalam paññapetunti
translated: Is it possible to point out a fruit of the homeless life, visible here and now?’

original: Evaṁ vutte, bhante, ajito kesakambalo maṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: evam vutte bhante ajitaḥ kesakambalaḥ mam etat avoca
translated: When I had spoken, Master Ajita said:

original: ‘natthi, mahārāja, dinnaṁ, natthi yiṭṭhaṁ, natthi hutaṁ, natthi sukatadukkaṭānaṁ
analyzed: natthi mahā rāja dinna natthi natthi huta natthi su kata dukkaṭāna
translated: ‘Great king, there is nothing given, nothing offered, nothing sacrificed.🔽There is no fruit or result of good or bad actions.

original: kammānaṁ phalaṁ vipāko, natthi ayaṁ loko, natthi paro loko, natthi mātā, natthi pitā,🔽natthi sattā opapātikā, natthi loke samaṇabrāhmaṇā sammaggatā sammāpaṭipannā, ye
analyzed: kammānam phalam vipākaḥ natthi ayam lokaḥ natthi paraḥ lokaḥ natthi mātā natthi pitā  natthi sattā opapātikā natthi loke samaṇa brāhmaṇā sammaggatā sammāpaṭipannā ye
translated: There is no this world or the next. There is no mother or father.

original: imañca lokaṁ parañca lokaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedenti.
analyzed: iman ca lokam paran ca lokam sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedenti
translated: There are no spontaneously arisen beings. There are in the world no ascetics or brahmins who have attained the highest point, who have reached the highest point, and who proclaim this world and the next on the basis of their own experience.

original: Cātumahābhūtiko ayaṁ puriso, yadā kālaṁ karoti, pathavī pathavikāyaṁ anupeti anupagacchati,
analyzed: cātumahābhūtikaḥ ayam purisaḥ yadā kālam karoti pathavī pathavi kāyam anupeti anupagacchati
translated: When a man dies, the earth in his body returns to the earth-element,🔽

original: āpo āpokāyaṁ anupeti anupagacchati, tejo tejokāyaṁ anupeti anupagacchati, vāyo vāyokāyaṁ
analyzed: āpaḥ āpokāyam anupeti anupagacchati tejo tejaḥkāyam anupeti anupagacchati vāyo vāyokāya
translated: When a man dies, his body is made up of the four great elements, and when he is burnt up, the earth-element in his body returns to the earth-element, the water-element in his body returns to the water-element, the fire-element in his body returns to the fire-element, and the air-element in his body returns to the air-element.

original: anupeti anupagacchati, ākāsaṁ indriyāni saṅkamanti.🔽Āsandipañcamā purisā mataṁ ādāya gacchanti.🔽Yāvāḷāhanā padāni paññāyanti.
analyzed: anupeti anupagacchati ākāsam indriyāni saṅkamanti  āsandi pañcamāḥ purisāḥ matam ādāya gacchanti  yāva āḷāhanā padāni paññāyanti
translated: The faculties are dispersed into space.🔽Four men with a bier carry off the corpse.🔽The footprints sink into the ground.

original: Kāpotakāni aṭṭhīni bhavanti, bhassantā āhutiyo.
analyzed: kāpotakāni aṭṭhīni bhavanti bhassantā āhutiyaḥ
translated: The bones turn white.🔽The offerings are scattered.

original: Dattupaññattaṁ yadidaṁ dānaṁ.
analyzed: dattu paññattam yat idam dāna
translated: The gifts are wasted.

original: Tesaṁ tucchaṁ musā vilāpo ye keci atthikavādaṁ vadanti.
analyzed: tesam tuccham musā vilāpaḥ ye keci atthika vādam vadanti
translated: Those who say that there is something after death are just prattling nonsense.

original: Bāle ca paṇḍite ca kāyassa bhedā ucchijjanti vinassanti, na honti paraṁ maraṇā’ti.
analyzed: bāle ca paṇḍite ca kāyassa bhedāḥ ucchijjanti vinassanti na honti param maraṇā ati
translated: Both the fool and the wise man are cut off and perish when the body dissolves, and do not exist after death.’

original: Itthaṁ kho me, bhante, ajito kesakambalo sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ puṭṭho samāno ucchedaṁ byākāsi.
analyzed: ittham kho me bhante ajitaḥ kesakambalaḥ sandiṭṭhikam sāmañña phalam puṭṭhaḥ samānaḥ ucchedam byākāsi
translated: ‘Lord, when I was questioned by Ajita Kesakamball about the visible fruit of recluseship, I answered as was taught by the Lord,

original: Seyyathāpi, bhante, ambaṁ vā puṭṭho labujaṁ byākareyya, labujaṁ vā puṭṭho ambaṁ byākareyya;🔽evameva kho me, bhante, ajito kesakambalo sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ puṭṭho samāno ucchedaṁ byākāsi.
analyzed: seyyathā api bhante ambam vā puṭṭhaḥ labujam byākareyya labujam vā puṭṭhaḥ ambam byākareyya  evam eva kho me bhante ajitaḥ kesakambalaḥ sandiṭṭhikam sāmañña phalam puṭṭhaḥ samānaḥ ucchedam byākāsi
translated: Just as if asked about a mango he were to describe a breadfruit tree,🔽so too, when asked about the fruit of the contemplative life visible here and now, Ajita described annihilation.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhante, etadahosi:
analyzed: tassa mayha bhante
translated: I thought:

original: ‘kathañhi nāma mādiso samaṇaṁ vā brāhmaṇaṁ vā vijite vasantaṁ apasādetabbaṁ maññeyyā’ti.
analyzed: katham hi nāma mādisaḥ samaṇam vā brāhmaṇam vā vijite vasantam apasādetabbam maññeyya ati
translated: ‘How can someone like me think to disparage a contemplative or brāhmaṇa who lives in my realm?’

original: So kho ahaṁ, bhante, ajitassa kesakambalassa bhāsitaṁ neva abhinandiṁ nappaṭikkosiṁ.
analyzed: saḥ kho aha bhante ajitassa kesakambalassa bhāsitam na iva abhinandim na paṭikkosi
translated: So I neither rejoiced in the statement of Ajita Kesakambala nor did I reject it.

original: Anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā anattamano anattamanavācaṁ anicchāretvā tameva vācaṁ anuggaṇhanto anikkujjanto uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamiṁ.
analyzed: an abhinanditvā ap paṭikkositvā an atta manaḥ an atta mana vācam an icchāretvā tam eva vācam anuggaṇhantaḥ a nikkujjantaḥ uṭṭhāya āsanā pakkami
translated: Neither rejoicing nor rejecting it, I asked neither his permission to leave nor took leave of him. Without doing either, I got up from my seat and left.

original: 3.4. Pakudhakaccāyanavāda
analyzed: pakudha kacca ayana vāda
translated: .. Pakudha Kaccāyana’s View

original: Ekamidāhaṁ, bhante, samayaṁ yena pakudho kaccāyano tenupasaṅkamiṁ; upasaṅkamitvā pakudhena kaccāyanena saddhiṁ sammodiṁ.
analyzed: ekam id āha bhante samayam yena pakudhaḥ kaccāyano tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā pakudhena kaccāyanena saddhim sammodi
translated: On one occasion I went to Pakudha Kaccāyana and exchanged greetings with him.

original: Sammodanīyaṁ kathaṁ sāraṇīyaṁ vītisāretvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁ. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho ahaṁ, bhante, pakudhaṁ kaccāyanaṁ etadavocaṁ:
analyzed: sammodanīyam katham sāraṇīyam vītisāretvā ekamantam nisīdi ekamantam nisinnaḥ kho aha bhante pakudham kaccāyanam etat avoca
translated: and after exchanging polite and courteous greetings, he sat down to one side. I then said to him:🔽

original: ‘yathā nu kho imāni, bho kaccāyana, puthusippāyatanāni …pe…
analyzed: yathā nu kho imāni bho kaccāyana puthu sippa āyatanāni pe
translated: After an exchange of friendly greetings & courtesies, he sat to one side. As he was sitting there, I said to him, ‘Master Kaccana, there are these various craftsmen…

original: sakkā nu kho, bho kaccāyana, evameva diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ paññapetun’ti?🔽Evaṁ vutte, bhante, pakudho kaccāyano maṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: sakkā nu kho bho kaccāyana evam eva diṭṭhe iva dhamme sandiṭṭhikam sāmañña phalam paññapetunti  evam vutte bhante pakudho kaccāyanaḥ mam etat avoca
translated: … Is it possible to point out a fruit of the contemplative life—visible here & now—that is more satisfying than these?’

original: ‘sattime, mahārāja, kāyā akaṭā akaṭavidhā animmitā animmātā vañjhā kūṭaṭṭhā esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitā.
analyzed: satti ime mahā rāja kāyāḥ akaṭāḥ akaṭavidhāḥ a nimmitāḥ a nimmātāḥ vañjhā kūṭaṭṭhā esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitā
translated: When this was said, Master Kaccana said to me, ‘Great king, there are these seven properties that are not fabricated, not unfabricated, not brought about, not capable of being brought about, unformed, not capable of being formed, and baseless.

original: Te na iñjanti, na vipariṇamanti, na aññamaññaṁ byābādhenti, nālaṁ aññamaññassa sukhāya vā dukkhāya vā sukhadukkhāya vā.
analyzed: te na iñjanti na vipariṇamanti na aññam aññam byābādhenti na alam aññam aññassa sukhāya vā dukkhāya vā sukha dukkhāya vā
translated: They don’t shake, don’t waver, don’t waver strongly, don’t go away, don’t come back, don’t stand still. They don’t go to or come from anywhere.

original: Katame satta?
analyzed: katame satta
translated: What are the seven?

original: Pathavikāyo, āpokāyo, tejokāyo, vāyokāyo, sukhe, dukkhe, jīve sattame—
analyzed: pathavi kāyo āpo kāyo tejo kāyo vāyo kāyo sukhe dukkhe jīve sattame
translated: The earth property, the liquid property, the fire property, the wind property, the space property, the consciousness property, and the life property.

original: ime satta kāyā akaṭā akaṭavidhā animmitā animmātā vañjhā kūṭaṭṭhā esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitā.🔽Te na iñjanti, na vipariṇamanti, na aññamaññaṁ byābādhenti, nālaṁ aññamaññassa sukhāya vā dukkhāya vā sukhadukkhāya vā.
analyzed: ime satta kāyāḥ akaṭāḥ akaṭavidhāḥ animmitāḥ animmātāḥ vañjhā kūṭaṭṭhā esikaṭṭhāyiṭṭhitā  te na iñjanti na vipariṇamanti na aññam aññam byābādhenti na alam aññam aññassa sukhāya vā dukkhāya vā sukha dukkhāya vā
translated: These seven bodies are unmade, they are not bent, they are not created, they are not caused to be, they are barren, they stand, they do not tremble, they are not capable of trembling.🔽They do not afflict each other, they are not capable of afflicting each other, they are not capable of pleasure or pain or pleasure and pain.

original: Tattha natthi hantā vā ghātetā vā, sotā vā sāvetā vā, viññātā vā viññāpetā vā.
analyzed: tattha natthi hantā vā ghātetā vā sotā vā sāvetā vā viññātā vā viññāpetā vā
translated: There is no doer of a deed here, no experiencer of the result. There is no bondage, no liberation.

original: Yopi tiṇhena satthena sīsaṁ chindati, na koci kiñci jīvitā voropeti;
analyzed: yaḥ api tiṇhena satthena sīsam chindati na koci kiñci jīvitā voropeti
translated: Even if one were to cut off one’s head with a sharp sword, one would not kill anyone.

original: sattannaṁ tveva kāyānamantarena satthaṁ vivaramanupatatī’ti.
analyzed: tu eva kāyānam antarena sattham vivaram anupatati iti
translated: The sword merely passes through the space between the seven bodies.’

original: Itthaṁ kho me, bhante, pakudho kaccāyano sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ puṭṭho samāno aññena aññaṁ byākāsi.
analyzed: ittham kho me bhante pakudhaḥ kaccāyanaḥ sandiṭṭhikam sāmañña phalam puṭṭhaḥ samānaḥ aññena aññam byākāsi
translated: “When I asked Pakudha Kaccāyana about the fruit of the homeless life, visible here and now, he evaded the question, giving a rambling answer on an unrelated topic.

original: Seyyathāpi, bhante, ambaṁ vā puṭṭho labujaṁ byākareyya, labujaṁ vā puṭṭho ambaṁ byākareyya;
analyzed: seyyathā api bhante ambam vā puṭṭhaḥ labujam byākareyya labujam vā puṭṭhaḥ ambam byākareyya
translated: Just as if one asked about a mango would speak about a breadfruit, or as if one asked about a breadfruit would speak about a mango.

original: evameva kho me, bhante, pakudho kaccāyano sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ puṭṭho samāno aññena aññaṁ byākāsi.
analyzed: evam eva kho me bhante pakudho kaccāyanaḥ sandiṭṭhikam sāmañña phalam puṭṭhaḥ samānaḥ aññena aññam byākāsi
translated: In the same way, when I asked Pakudha Kaccāyana about the fruit of recluseship visible here and now, he couldn’t explain it to me.

analyzed: saḥ kho aha bhante pakudhassa kaccāyanassa bhāsitam na iva abhinandim na paṭikkosi

original: anabhinanditvā appaṭikkositvā anattamano, anattamanavācaṁ anicchāretvā tameva vācaṁ anuggaṇhanto anikkujjanto uṭṭhāyāsanā pakkamiṁ.

translated: Neither rejoicing nor rejecting, I neither approved nor disapproved. Without approving or disapproving, without taking on or taking down, I rose from my seat and left.

translated: He is restrained by the restraint of the body, the speech and the livelihood.🔽That is how a Nigantha is restrained in three ways.

original: Yato kho, mahārāja, nigaṇṭho evaṁ cātuyāmasaṁvarasaṁvuto hoti;

original: Itthaṁ kho me, bhante, nigaṇṭho nāṭaputto sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ puṭṭho samāno cātuyāmasaṁvaraṁ byākāsi.

analyzed: an abhinanditvā ap paṭikkositvā an atta manaḥ an atta mana vācam an icchāretvā tam eva vācam anuggaṇhantaḥ a nikkujjantaḥ uṭṭhāya āsanā pakkami
translated: Without delighting in his words or disapproving of them, I neither agreed nor disagreed with them. Without delighting in his words or disapproving of them, I neither agreed nor disagreed with them. I then rose from my seat and left.

original: idha te assa puriso dāso kammakāro pubbuṭṭhāyī pacchānipātī kiṅkārapaṭissāvī manāpacārī piyavādī mukhullokako.
analyzed: idha te assa purisaḥ dāsaḥ kamma kāraḥ pubbuṭṭhāyī pacchānipātī kiṅkāra paṭissāvī manāpa cārī piya vādī mukhullokakaḥ
translated: Suppose a man were your slave, your servant, your groom, rising up before you and retiring after you, doing whatever you want, agreeable in his conduct and speech, always obedient.

original: Tassa evamassa:
analyzed: tassa evamassa
translated: He might think:

original: ‘acchariyaṁ, vata bho, abbhutaṁ, vata bho, puññānaṁ gati, puññānaṁ vipāko.
analyzed: acchariya vata bho abbhuta vata bho puññānam gati puññānam vipākaḥ
translated: ‘It’s amazing, it’s astounding, how the destination and outcome of meritorious deeds!

original: Ayañhi rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto manusso; ahampi manusso.
analyzed: ayan hi rājā māgadhaḥ ajātasattu vedehiputto manussaḥ aham pi manussaḥ
translated: This King Ajatasattu of Magadha, the son of the Videhi queen, is a human being, and I too am a human being.

original: Ayañhi rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricāreti, devo maññe.
analyzed: ayan hi rājā māgadhaḥ ajātasattu vedehiputto pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappitaḥ samaṅgībhūto paricāreti devaḥ maññe
translated: This King Ajatasattu of Magadha, the son of the Videhi queen, is endowed and provided with the five cords of sensual pleasure, and he delights in them, enjoys them, and indulges in them like a deva.

original: Ahaṁ panamhissa dāso kammakāro pubbuṭṭhāyī pacchānipātī kiṅkārapaṭissāvī manāpacārī piyavādī mukhullokako.
analyzed: aham pana amhissa dāsaḥ kamma kāraḥ pubbuṭṭhāyī pacchānipātī kiṅkāra paṭissāvī manāpa cārī piya vādī mukhullokako
translated: But I am his slave, his servant, his groom, rising up before him and retiring after him, doing whatever he wants, agreeable in my conduct and speech, always obedient.

original: So vatassāhaṁ puññāni kareyyaṁ.
analyzed: saḥ vatassa aham puññāni kareyya
translated: I should perform meritorious deeds.’

original: Yannūnāhaṁ kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajeyyan’ti.
analyzed: yat nūna aham kesa massuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni a chādetvā agārasma anagāriyam pabbajeyyanti
translated: Why don’t I shave off my hair & beard, put on the ocher robes, and go forth from the home life into homelessness?’

original: So aparena samayena kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajeyya.
analyzed: saḥ aparena samayena kesa massuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasma anagāriyam pabbajeyya
translated: “So after some time he shaves off his hair & beard, puts on the ocher robes, and goes forth from the home life into homelessness.

original: So evaṁ pabbajito samāno kāyena saṁvuto vihareyya, vācāya saṁvuto vihareyya, manasā saṁvuto vihareyya, ghāsacchādanaparamatāya santuṭṭho, abhirato paviveke.🔽Tañce te purisā evamāroceyyuṁ:
analyzed: so evam pabbajitaḥ samānaḥ kāyena savutaḥ vihareyya vācāya savutaḥ vihareyya manasā savutaḥ vihareyya ghāsa chādana parama tāya santuṭṭhaḥ abhirataḥ paviveke  tat ced te purisāḥ evam āroceyyu
translated: “Having gone forth in this way, he would abide with his body withdrawn but not his mind. He would be uninquisitive, difficult to teach, and not receptive to advice. He would not be one to undertake in earnest the training of a monastic for the sake of attaining the unattained, achieving the unachieved, and realizing the unrealized.

original: ‘yagghe, deva, jāneyyāsi, yo te so puriso dāso kammakāro pubbuṭṭhāyī pacchānipātī kiṅkārapaṭissāvī manāpacārī piyavādī mukhullokako;
analyzed: yat he deva jāneyyāsi yaḥ te saḥ purisaḥ dāso kamma kāro pubbuṭṭhāyī pacchānipātī kiṅkāra paṭissāvī manāpa cārī piya vādī mukhullokakaḥ
translated: “Then those people would inform you, ‘Your majesty, you should know that the man you had in mind as your slave, laborer, and worker—the one who got up before you, went to bed after you, and did what pleased you—

original: so, deva, kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito.
analyzed: saḥ deva kesa massum ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasma anagāriyam pabbajitaḥ
translated: has shaved off his hair & beard, put on the ocher robes, and gone forth from the home life into homelessness.’🔽“

original: So evaṁ pabbajito samāno kāyena saṁvuto viharati, vācāya saṁvuto viharati, manasā saṁvuto viharati, ghāsacchādanaparamatāya santuṭṭho, abhirato paviveke’ti.
analyzed: so evam pabbajitaḥ samāno kāyena savutaḥ viharati vācāya savutaḥ viharati manasā savutaḥ viharati ghāsa chādana paramatāya santuṭṭhaḥ abhirataḥ paviveka iti
translated: and after going forth he abides restrained in body, speech, and mind, content with the simplest food and shelter, and being a forest-dweller, he is satisfied with whatever resting place he finds.

original: Api nu tvaṁ evaṁ vadeyyāsi:
analyzed: api nu tvam evam vadeyyā asi
translated: Would you say to him:🔽‘Come, let this man be my slave, born of my loins, under my control, to do as I wish’?

original: ‘etu me, bho, so puriso, punadeva hotu dāso kammakāro pubbuṭṭhāyī pacchānipātī kiṅkārapaṭissāvī manāpacārī piyavādī mukhullokako’”ti?
analyzed: etu me bho saḥ purisaḥ punadeva hotu dāsaḥ kamma kāro pubbuṭṭhāyī pacchānipātī kiṅkāra paṭissāvī manāpa cārī piya vādī mukhullokakaḥ iti
translated: ‘Let that man come back to me, and once again be a slave, a servant, doing his work, rising up at the right time, putting in long hours, diligent, carrying out his duties, speaking politely, doing what is pleasing and beneficial, intent on self-improvement.’?”🔽“

original: “No hetaṁ, bhante.
analyzed: naḥ heta bhante
translated: “No, venerable sir.

original: Atha kho naṁ mayameva abhivādeyyāmapi, paccuṭṭheyyāmapi, āsanenapi nimanteyyāma,
analyzed: atha khalu nam mayam eva abhivādeyyām api paccuṭṭheyyām api āsanena api nimanteyyāma
translated: We would do homage to him, stand up for him, and offer him a seat.

original: abhinimanteyyāmapi naṁ cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārehi,
analyzed: abhinimanteyyām api nam cīvara piṇḍapāta senāsana gilāna ppaccaya bhesajja parikkhārehi
translated: We would provide him with robes, almsfood, resting place, and medicinal requisites.

original: dhammikampissa rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṁ saṁvidaheyyāmā”ti.
analyzed: dhammi kampissa rakkhā āvaraṇa guttim sa vidaheyyāma ati
translated: And we would arrange a guard and protector for him.”

original: “Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, mahārāja,
analyzed: tam kim maññasi mahā rāja
translated: “What do you think, great king?

original: yadi evaṁ sante hoti vā sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ no vā”ti?
analyzed: yadi evam sante hoti vā sandiṭṭhikam sāmañña phalam no vāti
translated: If that is so, is the fruit of recluseship visible here and now or not?”

original: “Addhā kho, bhante, evaṁ sante hoti sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalan”ti.
analyzed: addhā kho bhante evam sante hoti sandiṭṭhikam sāmañña phalanti
translated: “Surely, venerable sir, it is so in this case, that there is a fruit of the homeless life visible here and now.”

original: “Idaṁ kho te, mahārāja, mayā paṭhamaṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ paññattan”ti.
analyzed: idam kho te mahā rāja mayā paṭhamam diṭṭhe iva dhamme sandiṭṭhikam sāmañña phalam paññattanti
translated: “This, great king, is the first fruit of the homeless life that is visible here and now that has been declared to me by the Blessed One, with whom I am well pleased and satisfied.”

original: 4.2. Dutiyasandiṭṭhikasāmaññaphala
analyzed: dutiya sandiṭṭhika sāmañña phala
translated: … The second fruit of the homeless life visible here and now

original: “Sakkā pana, bhante, aññampi evameva diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ paññapetun”ti?
analyzed: sakkā pana bhante aññam pi evam eva diṭṭhe iva dhamme sandiṭṭhikam sāmañña phalam paññapetunti
translated: “But, venerable sir, is it possible to point out a further fruit of the homeless life that is visible here and now?”

original: “Sakkā, mahārāja.
analyzed: sakkā mahā rāja
translated: “It is possible, great king.

original: Tena hi, mahārāja, taññevettha paṭipucchissāmi. Yathā te khameyya, tathā naṁ byākareyyāsi.🔽Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, mahārāja,🔽idha te assa puriso kassako gahapatiko karakārako rāsivaḍḍhako.
analyzed: tena hi mahā rāja tat na eva īttha paṭipucchissāmi yathā te khameyya tathā nam byākareyyāsi  tam kim maññasi mahā rāja  idha te assa puriso kassakaḥ gahapatikaḥ karakārako rāsivaḍḍhako
translated: Well then, great king, I will ask you about this matter in return. What do you think, great king?🔽Suppose a man were your enemy, wishing for your harm, seeking your vulnerability, thinking, ‘How can I get the better of my enemy?’

original: Tassa evamassa:
analyzed: tassa evamassa
translated: Then you would be thinking:

original: ‘acchariyaṁ vata bho, abbhutaṁ vata bho, puññānaṁ gati, puññānaṁ vipāko.
analyzed: acchariyam vata bho abbhutam vata bho puññānam gati puññānam vipākaḥ
translated: ‘It is wonderful, it is marvellous! This is the destination and outcome of one who is not virtuous,

original: Ayañhi rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto manusso, ahampi manusso.
analyzed: ayan hi rājā māgadhaḥ ajātasattu vedehiputto manussaḥ aham pi manussaḥ
translated: for this King Ajātasattu of Magadha is a human being, and I too am a human being.

original: Ayañhi rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappito samaṅgībhūto paricāreti, devo maññe.
analyzed: ayan hi rājā māgadhaḥ ajātasattu vedehiputto pañcahi kāmaguṇehi samappitaḥ samaṅgībhūto paricāreti devaḥ maññe
translated: King Ajatasattu of Magadha, the son of the Videhi queen, is enjoying himself furnished and endowed with the five cords of sensual pleasure.

original: Ahaṁ panamhissa kassako gahapatiko karakārako rāsivaḍḍhako.
analyzed: aham pana amhissa kassakaḥ gahapatiko karakārako rāsivaḍḍhako
translated: But I am a farmer, a householder, a money-maker, an accumulator of wealth.

original: So vatassāhaṁ puññāni kareyyaṁ.
analyzed: saḥ vatassa aham puññāni kareyya
translated: I should make merit.

original: Yannūnāhaṁ kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajeyyan’ti.
analyzed: yat nūna aham kesa massuṃ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni a chādetvā agārasma anagāriyam pabbajeyyanti
translated: Why don’t I shave off my hair and beard, put on the yellow robe, and go forth from the home life into homelessness?’

original: So aparena samayena appaṁ vā bhogakkhandhaṁ pahāya mahantaṁ vā bhogakkhandhaṁ pahāya,🔽appaṁ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṁ pahāya mahantaṁ vā ñātiparivaṭṭaṁ pahāya kesamassuṁ ohāretvā
analyzed: so aparena samayena appam vā bhogakkhandham pahāya mahantam vā bhogakkhandham pahāya  appam vā ñāti parivaṭṭam pahāya mahantam vā ñāti parivaṭṭam pahāya kesa massuṃ ohāretvā
translated: “Then after some time he abandons a small amount of wealth, or a large amount of wealth;

original: kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajeyya.
analyzed: kāsāyāni vatthāni a chādetvā agārasma anagāriyam pabbajeyya
translated: abandons a small circle of relatives, or a large circle of relatives, and shaves off his hair and beard, puts on the yellow robe, and goes forth from the home life into homelessness.

original: So evaṁ pabbajito samāno kāyena saṁvuto vihareyya, vācāya saṁvuto vihareyya, manasā saṁvuto vihareyya, ghāsacchādanaparamatāya santuṭṭho, abhirato paviveke.
analyzed: so evam pabbajitaḥ samānaḥ kāyena savutaḥ vihareyya vācāya savutaḥ vihareyya manasā savutaḥ vihareyya ghāsa chādana parama tāya santuṭṭhaḥ abhirataḥ paviveke
translated: “Having gone forth in this way, he would dwell restrained by the restraint of the Monastic Law, perfect in conduct and resort, seen and esteemed by good men, confident in the training.🔽He would be content with any kind of robes, almsfood, lodgings, and medicines and provisions for the sick.

original: Tañce te purisā evamāroceyyuṁ:🔽‘yagghe, deva, jāneyyāsi, yo te so puriso kassako gahapatiko karakārako rāsivaḍḍhako;
analyzed: tat ced te purisāḥ evam āroceyyu  yat he deva jāneyyāsi yaḥ te saḥ puriso kassakaḥ gahapatiko karakārako rāsivaḍḍhako
translated: “If people were to tell you:

original: so deva kesamassuṁ ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito.
analyzed: saḥ deva kesa massum ohāretvā kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasma anagāriyam pabbajitaḥ
translated: ‘Your farmer, your householder, your money-lender, your trader, who used to work hard, get up at the right time, work diligently, and not be wasteful of his income, has shaved off his hair and beard, put on the ocher robes, and gone forth from the home life into homelessness.

original: So evaṁ pabbajito samāno kāyena saṁvuto viharati, vācāya saṁvuto viharati, manasā saṁvuto viharati, ghāsacchādanaparamatāya santuṭṭho, abhirato paviveke’ti.
analyzed: so evam pabbajitaḥ samāno kāyena savutaḥ viharati vācāya savutaḥ viharati manasā savutaḥ viharati ghāsa chādana paramatāya santuṭṭhaḥ abhirataḥ paviveka iti
translated: Since going forth he has lived restrained in body, speech, and mind, gratified with the simplest food and shelter, and content.’

original: Api nu tvaṁ evaṁ vadeyyāsi:
analyzed: api nu tvam evam vadeyyā asi
translated: Would you say to them:

original: ‘etu me, bho, so puriso, punadeva hotu kassako gahapatiko karakārako rāsivaḍḍhako’”ti?
analyzed: etu me bho saḥ purisaḥ punadeva hotu kassakaḥ gahapatiko karakārako rāsivaḍḍhako ti
translated: ‘Let him come back, let him be as he was before’?”

original: “No hetaṁ, bhante.🔽Atha kho naṁ mayameva abhivādeyyāmapi, paccuṭṭheyyāmapi, āsanenapi nimanteyyāma,
analyzed: naḥ heta bhante  atha khalu nam mayam eva abhivādeyyām api paccuṭṭheyyām api āsanena api nimanteyyāma
translated: “No, venerable sir.

original: abhinimanteyyāmapi naṁ cīvarapiṇḍapātasenāsanagilānappaccayabhesajjaparikkhārehi,
analyzed: abhinimanteyyām api nam cīvara piṇḍapāta senāsana gilāna ppaccaya bhesajja parikkhārehi
translated: We would pay homage to him, rise up for him, invite him to take the best seat, invite him to accept dwellings, supplies of the requisites, and so on.

original: dhammikampissa rakkhāvaraṇaguttiṁ saṁvidaheyyāmā”ti.
analyzed: dhammi kampissa rakkhā āvaraṇa guttim sa vidaheyyāma ati
translated: and I would provide him with protection, guard, and defense.”

original: “Taṁ kiṁ maññasi, mahārāja?
analyzed: tam kim maññasi mahā rāja
translated: “What do you think, great king?

original: Yadi evaṁ sante hoti vā sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ no vā”ti?
analyzed: yadi evam sante hoti vā sandiṭṭhikam sāmañña phalam no vāti
translated: If that is so, is there or is there not a fruit of the contemplative life apparent here and now?”

original: “Addhā kho, bhante, evaṁ sante hoti sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalan”ti.
analyzed: addhā kho bhante evam sante hoti sandiṭṭhikam sāmañña phalanti
translated: “Certainly, venerable sir, if that is so, there is a fruit of the contemplative life apparent here and now.”

original: “Idaṁ kho te, mahārāja, mayā dutiyaṁ diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ paññattan”ti.
analyzed: idam kho te mahā rāja mayā dutiyam diṭṭhe iva dhamme sandiṭṭhikam sāmañña phalam paññattanti
translated: “This, great king, is the second fruit of the contemplative life visible here and now that has been declared to me by the Blessed One, with its culmination and its consummation, not held in common with any other sectarians, and that I enjoy as a recluse under the Blessed One.”

original: 4.3. Paṇītatarasāmaññaphala
analyzed: paṇītatara sāmañña phala
translated: … A still more excellent fruit of the contemplative life

original: “Sakkā pana, bhante, aññampi diṭṭheva dhamme sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ paññapetuṁ imehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmaññaphalehi abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañcā”ti?
analyzed: sakkā pana bhante aññam pi diṭṭhe iva dhamme sandiṭṭhikam sāmañña phalam paññapetum imehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmañña phalehi abhikkantataram ca paṇītataram ca ati
translated: “But, venerable sir, is it possible to point out a fruit of the contemplative life still more excellent and sublime than this fruit of the contemplative life apparent here and now?”

original: “Sakkā, mahārāja.
analyzed: sakkā mahā rāja
translated: “It is possible, great king.

original: Tena hi, mahārāja, suṇohi, sādhukaṁ manasi karohi, bhāsissāmī”ti.
analyzed: tena hi mahā rāja suṇohi sādhukam manasi karohi bhāsissāmi iti
translated: Listen and attend closely to what I shall say.”

original: “Evaṁ, bhante”ti kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto bhagavato paccassosi.
analyzed: eva bhante iti kho rājā māgadhaḥ ajātasattu vedehiputto bhagavataḥ paccassosi
translated: “Yes, venerable sir,” the king of Magadha, Ajatasattu, the son of Lady Wisdom, replied.

original: Bhagavā etadavoca:
analyzed: bhagavān etat avoca
translated: The Blessed One said this:

original: “idha, mahārāja, tathāgato loke uppajjati arahaṁ sammāsambuddho vijjācaraṇasampanno sugato lokavidū anuttaro purisadammasārathi satthā devamanussānaṁ buddho bhagavā.
analyzed: idha mahā rāja tathāgataḥ loke uppajjati araham sammāsambuddhaḥ vijjā caraṇa sampannaḥ sugataḥ loka vidū anuttaraḥ purisa damma sārathi satthā deva manussānam buddhaḥ bhagavā
translated: “Here, sire, a Tathāgata appears in the world, accomplished, fully enlightened …

original: So imaṁ lokaṁ sadevakaṁ samārakaṁ sabrahmakaṁ sassamaṇabrāhmaṇiṁ pajaṁ sadevamanussaṁ sayaṁ abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti.
analyzed: saḥ imam lokam sa devakam sa mārakam sa brahmakam sa ssamaṇa brāhmaṇim pajam sa deva manussam sayam abhiññā sacchikatvā pavedeti
translated: He reveals this world—with its devas, Māras and Brahmās, this generation with its contemplatives and brahmans, its royalty and common people—having understood and realized it for himself.

original: So dhammaṁ deseti ādikalyāṇaṁ majjhekalyāṇaṁ pariyosānakalyāṇaṁ sātthaṁ sabyañjanaṁ, kevalaparipuṇṇaṁ parisuddhaṁ brahmacariyaṁ pakāseti.
analyzed: saḥ dhammam deseti ādi kalyāṇam majjhe kalyāṇam pariyosāna kalyāṇam sa attham sa byañjana kevala paripuṇṇam parisuddham brahmacariyam pakāseti
translated: He teaches the Dhamma that is good in the beginning, good in the middle, and good in the end, with its own meaning, with its own phrasing, and reveals a holy life that is utterly perfect and pure.

original: Taṁ dhammaṁ suṇāti gahapati vā gahapatiputto vā aññatarasmiṁ vā kule paccājāto.
analyzed: tam dhammam suṇāti gahapati vā gahapati putto vā aññatarasmim vā kule paccājātaḥ
translated: A householder or householder’s son or one born in some other clan hears that Dhamma.

original: So taṁ dhammaṁ sutvā tathāgate saddhaṁ paṭilabhati.
analyzed: saḥ tam dhammam sutvā tathāgate saddham paṭilabhati
translated: Having heard that Dhamma he acquires faith in the Tathāgata.

original: So tena saddhāpaṭilābhena samannāgato iti paṭisañcikkhati:
analyzed: saḥ tena saddhā paṭilābhena samannāgataḥ iti paṭisañcikkhati
translated: Endowed with that faith he considers thus:

original: ‘sambādho gharāvāso rajopatho, abbhokāso pabbajjā.
analyzed: sambādhaḥ gharāvāsaḥ rajopathaḥ abbhokāsaḥ pabbajjā
translated: ‘A crowded home is a dusty place; the life gone forth is free from dust.

original: Nayidaṁ sukaraṁ agāraṁ ajjhāvasatā ekantaparipuṇṇaṁ ekantaparisuddhaṁ saṅkhalikhitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ carituṁ.
analyzed: na idam sukaram agāram ajjhāvasatā ekanta paripuṇṇam ekanta parisuddham saṅkha likhitam brahmacariyam caritu
translated: It’s not easy to live the spiritual life in the home, limited, cramped, dusty, & dirty, as though in a little cage.

translated: Why don’t I shave my head & beard, put on the ocher robes, and go forth from the home life into homelessness?’

original: kāsāyāni vatthāni acchādetvā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajati.🔽So evaṁ pabbajito samāno pātimokkhasaṁvarasaṁvuto viharati ācāragocarasampanno, aṇumattesu
analyzed: kāsāyāni vatthāni a chādetvā agārasma anagāriyam pabbajati  saḥ evam pabbajitaḥ samānaḥ pātimokkha savara savutaḥ viharati ācāra gocara sampannaḥ aṇumattesu
translated: “Then, after some time, he abandons a small or large fortune, abandons a small or large circle of relatives, shaves his head & beard, puts on the ocher robes, and goes forth from the home life into homelessness.

original: vajjesu bhayadassāvī, samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu, kāyakammavacīkammena samannāgato
analyzed: vajjesu bhaya dassāvī samādāya sikkhati sikkhāpadesu kāya kamma vacī kammena samannāgataḥ
translated: “Having gone forth in this way, he lives restrained under the Monastic Code, trains in the Monastic Code, and lives observing the Monastic Code, perfect in conduct & resort, seeing danger in the slightest faults, training in the Monastic Code.🔽He is virtuous, abides restrained with the Pāṭimokkha, and is endowed with (good) conduct & resort, seeing danger in the slightest faults, and trains in the Monastic Code.

original: kusalena, parisuddhājīvo sīlasampanno, indriyesu guttadvāro, satisampajaññena samannāgato, santuṭṭho.
analyzed: kusalena parisuddha ājīvaḥ sīla sampannaḥ indriyesu gutta dvāro sati sampajaññena samannāgato santuṭṭho
translated: He is virtuous, of pure livelihood, perfect in his practice, guarded in his senses, mindful and self-possessed, and contented.

original: 4.3.1. Sīla🔽4.3.1.1. Cūḷasīla

original: Idha, mahārāja, bhikkhu pāṇātipātaṁ pahāya pāṇātipātā paṭivirato hoti. Nihitadaṇḍo nihitasattho lajjī dayāpanno sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī viharati.

translated: Here, sire, a bhikkhu, having abandoned the killing of living beings, abstains from killing living beings; he dwells with his rod laid down, his knife laid down, scrupulous, merciful, compassionate for the good of all living beings.

original: Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṁ.
analyzed: idam pissa hoti sīlasmi

original: Adinnādānaṁ pahāya adinnādānā paṭivirato hoti dinnādāyī dinnapāṭikaṅkhī, athenena sucibhūtena attanā viharati.

translated: Having abandoned taking what is not given, he abstains from taking what is not given; he takes only what is given, expects only what is given, by not stealing he abides in purity.

original: Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṁ.
analyzed: idam pissa hoti sīlasmi
translated: This is virtue on his part.

original: Abrahmacariyaṁ pahāya brahmacārī hoti ārācārī virato methunā gāmadhammā.
