translated: Having abandoned unchastity, he observes chastity; he dwells remote, a forsaker of sensual desires.

original: Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṁ.
analyzed: idam pissa hoti sīlasmi
translated: This is virtue on his part.

original: Musāvādaṁ pahāya musāvādā paṭivirato hoti saccavādī saccasandho theto paccayiko avisaṁvādako lokassa.

original: Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṁ.
analyzed: idam pissa hoti sīlasmi
translated: This is how there is morality in him.

original: Idampissa hoti sīlasmiṁ.

translated: “Abandoning harsh speech, he abstains from harsh speech. He speaks only such words as are gentle, pleasing to the ear, endearing, going to the heart, urbane, amiable, and agreeable to the many-folk.

analyzed: idam pissa hoti sīlasmi  samphappalāpam pahāya samphappalāpā paṭivirataḥ hoti kāla vādī bhūta vādī attha vādī

original: akusalā dhammā anvāssaveyyuṁ, tassa saṁvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati cakkhundriyaṁ,
analyzed: akusalāḥ dhammāḥ anvāssaveyyu tassa savarāya paṭipajjati rakkhati cakkhu indriya
translated: Since, if he left the eye faculty unguarded, bad, unwholesome states of longing and dejection might invade him, he practices guarding it, he protects the eye faculty, he achieves restraint over it.

original: cakkhundriye saṁvaraṁ āpajjati.
analyzed: cakkhu indriye savaram āpajjati
translated: He enters upon the way of its restraint.

original: Sotena saddaṁ sutvā …pe…🔽ghānena gandhaṁ ghāyitvā …pe…
analyzed: sotena saddam sutvā pe  ghānena gandham ghāyitvā pe
translated: When he hears a sound with the ear…🔽when he smells an odour with the nose…

original: jivhāya rasaṁ sāyitvā …pe…
analyzed: jivhāya rasam sāyitvā pe
translated: when he tastes a flavour with the tongue…

original: kāyena phoṭṭhabbaṁ phusitvā …pe…
analyzed: kāyena phoṭṭhabbam phusitvā pe
translated: when he feels an object with the body…

original: manasā dhammaṁ viññāya na nimittaggāhī hoti nānubyañjanaggāhī.
analyzed: manasā dhammam viññāya na nimitta ggāhī hoti na anubyañjana ggāhī
translated: when he knows a mind-object with the mind, a bhikkhu does not grasp at its signs and features.

original: Yatvādhikaraṇamenaṁ manindriyaṁ asaṁvutaṁ viharantaṁ abhijjhā domanassā pāpakā akusalā
analyzed: yatvā adhikaraṇam enam manindriyam asavutam viharantam abhijjhāḥ domanassāḥ pāpakāḥ akusalāḥ
translated: Since, if he left the mind faculty unguarded, bad, unwholesome states of longing and dejection might invade him, he practices guarding it, he protects the mind faculty, he achieves restraint over it.

original: dhammā anvāssaveyyuṁ, tassa saṁvarāya paṭipajjati, rakkhati manindriyaṁ, manindriye saṁvaraṁ āpajjati.
analyzed: dhammāḥ anvāssaveyyu tassa savarāya paṭipajjati rakkhati manindriya manindriye savaram āpajjati
translated: he practices for the restraint of the faculties. He guards the faculty of the mind, he achieves restraint over the faculty of the mind.

original: So iminā ariyena indriyasaṁvarena samannāgato ajjhattaṁ abyāsekasukhaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti.
analyzed: saḥ iminā ariyena indriya savarena samannāgataḥ ajjhattam a byāseka sukham paṭisaveda iti
translated: Endowed with this noble restraint of the faculties he experiences within himself a bliss that is blameless.

original: Evaṁ kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu indriyesu guttadvāro hoti.
analyzed: evam kho mahā rāja bhikkhu indriyesu gutta dvāraḥ hoti
translated: It is in this way, sire, that a bhikkhu is one who guards the doors of his faculties.

original: 4.3.2.2. Satisampajañña
analyzed: sati sampajañña
translated: .... Mindfulness and clear awareness

original: Kathañca, mahārāja, bhikkhu satisampajaññena samannāgato hoti?🔽Idha, mahārāja, bhikkhu abhikkante paṭikkante sampajānakārī hoti, ālokite vilokite🔽sampajānakārī hoti, samiñjite pasārite sampajānakārī hoti, saṅghāṭipattacīvaradhāraṇe🔽sampajānakārī hoti, asite pīte khāyite sāyite sampajānakārī hoti, uccārapassāvakamme
analyzed: kathañca mahā rāja bhikkhu sati sampajaññena samannāgataḥ hoti  idha mahā rāja bhikkhu abhikkante paṭikkante sampajāna kārī hoti ālokite vilokite  sampajāna kārī hoti samiñjite pasārite sampajāna kārī hoti saṅghāṭi patta cīvara dhāraṇe  sampajāna kārī hoti asite pīte khāyite sāyite sampajāna kārī hoti uccāra passāva kamme
translated: And how, sire, is a bhikkhu endowed with mindfulness and clear awareness?

original: sampajānakārī hoti, gate ṭhite nisinne sutte jāgarite bhāsite tuṇhībhāve sampajānakārī hoti.
analyzed: sampajāna kārī hoti gate ṭhite nisinne sutte jāgarite bhāsite tuṇhībhāve sampajāna kārī hoti
translated: Here, sire, a bhikkhu is one who acts with clear awareness in going forth and back, in looking ahead or behind, in bending and stretching, in wearing the outer robe, inner robe and patched cloak, in handling the bowl, in eating, in drinking, in chewing and in tasting, in evacuating urine and excrement, in walking, in standing, in sitting, in sleeping, in waking, in talking, and in maintaining silence.

original: Evaṁ kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu satisampajaññena samannāgato hoti.
analyzed: evam kho mahā rāja bhikkhu sati sampajaññena samannāgataḥ hoti
translated: That, sire, is how a monk is possessed of mindfulness and clear consciousness.

original: 4.3.2.3. Santosa
analyzed: santosa
translated: .... Contentment

original: Kathañca, mahārāja, bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti?
analyzed: kathañca mahā rāja bhikkhu santuṭṭhaḥ hoti
translated: “And how, sire, is a monk contented?

original: Idha, mahārāja, bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti kāyaparihārikena cīvarena, kucchiparihārikena piṇḍapātena. So yena yeneva pakkamati, samādāyeva pakkamati.
analyzed: idha mahā rāja bhikkhu santuṭṭhaḥ hoti kāya parihārikena cīvarena kucchi parihārikena piṇḍapātena saḥ yena yena iva pakkamati samādāya iva pakkamati
translated: Here, sire, a monk is contented with a robe to protect his body and with alms to sustain his belly. Wherever he goes, he goes with these, taking nothing else with him.

original: Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, pakkhī sakuṇo yena yeneva ḍeti, sapattabhārova ḍeti;
analyzed: seyyathā api mahā rāja pakkhī sakuṇaḥ yena yena iva ḍeti sa patta bhāraḥ uva ḍeti
translated: Just as, sire, a bird, wherever it goes, flies with its wings as its only burden,

original: evameva kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti kāyaparihārikena cīvarena kucchiparihārikena piṇḍapātena. So yena yeneva pakkamati, samādāyeva pakkamati.
analyzed: evam eva kho mahā rāja bhikkhu santuṭṭhaḥ hoti kāya parihārikena cīvarena kucchi parihārikena piṇḍapātena saḥ yena yena iva pakkamati samādāya iva pakkamati
translated: even so, sire, a monk is contented with a robe to protect his body and with alms to sustain his belly. Wherever he goes, he goes with these, taking nothing else with him.

original: Evaṁ kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu santuṭṭho hoti.
analyzed: evam kho mahā rāja bhikkhu santuṭṭhaḥ hoti
translated: That, sire, is how a monk is contented.

original: 4.3.2.4. Nīvaraṇappahāna
analyzed: nīvaraṇa ppahāna
translated: .... Abandoning the Hindrances

original: So iminā ca ariyena sīlakkhandhena samannāgato, iminā ca ariyena indriyasaṁvarena
analyzed: saḥ iminā ca ariyena sīla kkhandhena samannāgataḥ iminā ca ariyena indriya savarena
translated: Endowed with this aggregate of virtue, this restraint of the faculties, this perfection of virtue,

original: samannāgato, iminā ca ariyena satisampajaññena samannāgato, imāya ca ariyāya santuṭṭhiyā samannāgato,
analyzed: samannāgataḥ iminā ca ariyena sati sampajaññena samannāgataḥ imāya ca ariyāya santuṭṭhiyā samannāgataḥ
translated: Endowed with this noble virtue, and with this noble restraint of the faculties, and with this noble contentment,

original: vivittaṁ senāsanaṁ bhajati araññaṁ rukkhamūlaṁ pabbataṁ kandaraṁ giriguhaṁ susānaṁ vanapatthaṁ abbhokāsaṁ palālapuñjaṁ.
analyzed: vivittam senāsanam bhajati araññam rukkha mūlam pabbatam kandaram giri guham su sānam vana pattham abbhokāsam palāla puñja
translated: he frequents a secluded lodging, a forest, the foot of a tree, a mountain, a ravine, a hillside cave, a charnel ground, a jungle thicket, an open space, a heap of straw.

original: So pacchābhattaṁ piṇḍapātapaṭikkanto nisīdati pallaṅkaṁ ābhujitvā ujuṁ kāyaṁ paṇidhāya parimukhaṁ satiṁ upaṭṭhapetvā.
analyzed: saḥ pacchābhattam piṇḍapāta paṭikkantaḥ nisīdati pallaṅkam ābhujitvā ujum kāyam paṇidhāya parimukham satim upaṭṭhapetvā
translated: After his meal, on his return from alms round, he sits down, crosses his legs, holds his body erect, and brings mindfulness to the fore.

original: So abhijjhaṁ loke pahāya vigatābhijjhena cetasā viharati, abhijjhāya cittaṁ parisodheti.
analyzed: saḥ abhijjham loke pahāya vigata abhijjhena cetasā viharati abhijjhāya cittam parisodheti
translated: He gives up longing for the world, and abides with a mind free from longing; he purifies his mind of longing.

original: Byāpādapadosaṁ pahāya abyāpannacitto viharati sabbapāṇabhūtahitānukampī, byāpādapadosā cittaṁ parisodheti.
analyzed: byāpāda padosam pahāya a byāpanna cittaḥ viharati sabba pāṇa bhūta hita anukampī byāpāda padosā cittam parisodheti
translated: He gives up ill will and malevolence, and abides with a mind free from ill will, compassionate for the welfare of all living beings; he purifies his mind of ill will.

original: Thinamiddhaṁ pahāya vigatathinamiddho viharati ālokasaññī, sato sampajāno, thinamiddhā cittaṁ parisodheti.
analyzed: thinamiddham pahāya vigata thinamiddhaḥ viharati āloka saññī sataḥ sampajānaḥ thinamiddhā cittam parisodheti
translated: He gives up dullness and drowsiness, and abides free from dullness and drowsiness, percipient of light, mindful and clearly comprehending; he purifies his mind of dullness and drowsiness.

original: Uddhaccakukkuccaṁ pahāya anuddhato viharati, ajjhattaṁ vūpasantacitto, uddhaccakukkuccā cittaṁ parisodheti.
analyzed: uddhacca kukkuccam pahāya anuddhataḥ viharati ajjhattam vūpasanta cittaḥ uddhacca kukkuccā cittam parisodheti
translated: He abandons restlessness and dwells without it, his mind inwardly peaceful. He purifies his mind from restlessness.

original: Vicikicchaṁ pahāya tiṇṇavicikiccho viharati, akathaṅkathī kusalesu dhammesu, vicikicchāya cittaṁ parisodheti.
analyzed: vicikiccham pahāya tiṇṇa vicikicchaḥ viharati a kathaṅkathī kusalesu dhammesu vicikicchāya cittam parisodheti
translated: He abandons doubt and dwells without it, crossing over uncertainty. He has no more perplexity about wholesome qualities. He purifies his mind from doubt.

original: Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, puriso iṇaṁ ādāya kammante payojeyya.
analyzed: sa iyyathā api mahā rāja purisaḥ iṇam ādāya kammante payojeyya
translated: Suppose a man took out a loan and undertook business.

original: Tassa te kammantā samijjheyyuṁ.
analyzed: tassa te kammantā samijjheyyu
translated: His business succeeded.

original: So yāni ca porāṇāni iṇamūlāni, tāni ca byantiṁ kareyya, siyā cassa uttariṁ avasiṭṭhaṁ dārabharaṇāya.
analyzed: saḥ yāni ca porāṇāni iṇa mūlāni tāni ca byantim kareyya siyā ca assa uttarim avasiṭṭham dāra bharaṇāya
translated: He was able to repay all his old debts and had some left over for his upkeep.

original: Tassa evamassa:
analyzed: tassa evamassa
translated: He might think:

original: ‘ahaṁ kho pubbe iṇaṁ ādāya kammante payojesiṁ.
analyzed: aham kho pubbe iṇam ādāya kammante payojesi
translated: ‘Formerly I took out a loan and undertook business.

original: Tassa me te kammantā samijjhiṁsu.
analyzed: tassa me te kammantā samijjhisu
translated: My business succeeded.

original: Sohaṁ yāni ca porāṇāni iṇamūlāni, tāni ca byantiṁ akāsiṁ, atthi ca me uttariṁ avasiṭṭhaṁ dārabharaṇāyā’ti.
analyzed: saḥ ham yāni ca porāṇāni iṇa mūlāni tāni ca akāsi atthi ca me uttarim avasiṭṭham dāra bharaṇāya ati
translated: I was able to repay all my old debts and have some left over for my upkeep.’

original: So tatonidānaṁ labhetha pāmojjaṁ, adhigaccheyya somanassaṁ.
analyzed: saḥ tatonidānam labhetha pāmojja adhigaccheyya somanassa
translated: He would experience joy and happiness on that account.

original: Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, puriso ābādhiko assa dukkhito bāḷhagilāno; bhattañcassa nacchādeyya, na cassa kāye balamattā.
analyzed: seyyathā api mahā rāja purisaḥ ābādhikaḥ assa dukkhitaḥ bāḷha gilānaḥ bhattam cassa na chādeyya na ca assa kāye bala mattā
translated: Suppose a man was sick, suffering, and gravely ill. He would not enjoy his food and his body would waste away from lack of nourishment.

original: So aparena samayena tamhā ābādhā mucceyya; bhattaṁ cassa chādeyya, siyā cassa kāye balamattā.
analyzed: saḥ aparena samayena tamhā ābādhā mucceyya bhattam cassa chādeyya siyā ca ssa kāye bala mattā
translated: But after some time he would recover from that sickness. He would enjoy his food and his body would wax strong from nourishment.

original: Tassa evamassa:
analyzed: tassa evamassa
translated: He might think:

original: ‘ahaṁ kho pubbe ābādhiko ahosiṁ dukkhito bāḷhagilāno;
analyzed: aham kho pubbe ābādhikaḥ ahosim dukkhitaḥ bāḷha gilānaḥ
translated: ‘Formerly I was sick, suffering, and gravely ill.

original: bhattañca me nacchādesi, na ca me āsi kāye balamattā.
analyzed: bhattam ca me na chādesi na ca me āsi kāye bala mattā
translated: I did not enjoy my food and my body wasted away from lack of nourishment.

original: Somhi etarahi tamhā ābādhā mutto;
analyzed: somhi etarahi tamhā ābādhā mutto
translated: But now I am recovered from that sickness.

original: bhattañca me chādeti, atthi ca me kāye balamattā’ti.
analyzed: bhattam ca me chādeti atthi ca me kāye balam attā ati
translated: I enjoy my food and my body waxes strong from nourishment.’

original: So tatonidānaṁ labhetha pāmojjaṁ, adhigaccheyya somanassaṁ.
analyzed: saḥ tatonidānam labhetha pāmojja adhigaccheyya somanassa
translated: He would feel joy and happiness on that account.

original: Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, puriso bandhanāgāre baddho assa.
analyzed: seyyathā api mahā rāja purisaḥ bandhanāgāre baddhaḥ assa
translated: Suppose a man was imprisoned in a jail.

original: So aparena samayena tamhā bandhanāgārā mucceyya sotthinā abbhayena, na cassa kiñci bhogānaṁ vayo.
analyzed: saḥ aparena samayena tamhā bandhanāgārā mucceyya sotthinā abbhayena na cassa kiñci
translated: But after some time he would be released from that prison, safe and secure, with no loss of his property.

original: Tassa evamassa:
analyzed: tassa evamassa
translated: He might think:

original: ‘ahaṁ kho pubbe bandhanāgāre baddho ahosiṁ, somhi etarahi tamhā bandhanāgārā mutto sotthinā abbhayena.
analyzed: aham kho pubbe bandhanāgāre baddhaḥ ahosi somhi etarahi tamhā bandhanāgārā mutto sotthinā abbhayena
translated: “Formerly, when I was imprisoned, I was released from that prison safe and sound.

original: Natthi ca me kiñci bhogānaṁ vayo’ti.
analyzed: natthi ca me kiñci
translated: And I have not lost any of my wealth.”

original: So tatonidānaṁ labhetha pāmojjaṁ, adhigaccheyya somanassaṁ.
analyzed: saḥ tatonidānam labhetha pāmojja adhigaccheyya somanassa
translated: He would obtain joy and happiness from that cause.

original: Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, puriso dāso assa anattādhīno parādhīno na yenakāmaṅgamo.
analyzed: seyyathā api mahā rāja purisaḥ dāsaḥ assa anatta adhīnaḥ para adhīnaḥ na yenakāmaṅgamaḥ
translated: “Suppose, sire, a man were a slave, not his own master, dependent on another, unable to go where he liked.

original: So aparena samayena tamhā dāsabyā mucceyya attādhīno aparādhīno bhujisso yenakāmaṅgamo.
analyzed: saḥ aparena samayena tamhā dāsabyāḥ mucceyya attā adhīnaḥ apara adhīnaḥ bhujissaḥ yena kāmaṅgamaḥ
translated: Later he would be freed from slavery, his own master, not dependent on another, a freeman able to go where he liked.

original: Tassa evamassa:
analyzed: tassa evamassa
translated: He would think:

original: ‘ahaṁ kho pubbe dāso ahosiṁ anattādhīno parādhīno na yenakāmaṅgamo.
analyzed: aham kho pubbe dāsaḥ ahosim anatta adhīnaḥ para adhīnaḥ na yenakāmaṅgamaḥ
translated: ‘Formerly, when I was a slave, I was not my own master, dependent on another, unable to go where I liked.

original: Somhi etarahi tamhā dāsabyā mutto attādhīno aparādhīno bhujisso yenakāmaṅgamo’ti.
analyzed: somhi etarahi tamhā dāsabyā muttaḥ attā adhīnaḥ apara adhīnaḥ bhujissaḥ yena kāmaṅgamaḥ ti
translated: Now I am freed from slavery, my own master, not dependent on another, a freeman able to go where I like.’

original: So tatonidānaṁ labhetha pāmojjaṁ, adhigaccheyya somanassaṁ.
analyzed: saḥ tatonidānam labhetha pāmojja adhigaccheyya somanassa
translated: He would obtain joy and happiness from that cause.

original: Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, puriso sadhano sabhogo kantāraddhānamaggaṁ paṭipajjeyya dubbhikkhaṁ sappaṭibhayaṁ.
analyzed: sa iyyathā api mahā rāja purisaḥ sa dhanaḥ sa bhogaḥ kantāra dhāna maggam paṭipajjeyya dubbhikkham sa paṭibhaya
translated: “Suppose, sire, a man with property and possessions were to set out on a journey through the desert, a place without water and dangerous,

original: So aparena samayena taṁ kantāraṁ nitthareyya sotthinā, gāmantaṁ anupāpuṇeyya khemaṁ appaṭibhayaṁ.
analyzed: saḥ aparena samayena tam kantāram nitthareyya sa utthinā gāmantam anupāpuṇeyya khemam appaṭibhaya
translated: Then after some time he would get safely through the desert and reach a village, a place of safety and freedom from danger.

original: Tassa evamassa:
analyzed: tassa evamassa
translated: He would think:

original: ‘ahaṁ kho pubbe sadhano sabhogo kantāraddhānamaggaṁ paṭipajjiṁ dubbhikkhaṁ sappaṭibhayaṁ.
analyzed: aham kho pubbe sa dhanaḥ sa bhogaḥ kantāra dhāna maggam paṭipajjim dubbhikkham sa ppaṭibhaya
translated: ‘Formerly, when I was travelling on the desert path, I was in debt, had creditors, and was threatened with being imprisoned.

original: Somhi etarahi taṁ kantāraṁ nitthiṇṇo sotthinā, gāmantaṁ anuppatto khemaṁ appaṭibhayan’ti.
analyzed: somhi etarahi tam kantāram nitthiṇṇaḥ sotthinā gāmantam an uppatto khemam appaṭibhayanti
translated: Now I have got safely through the desert and have reached a village, a place of safety and freedom from danger.’

original: So tatonidānaṁ labhetha pāmojjaṁ, adhigaccheyya somanassaṁ.
analyzed: saḥ tatonidānam labhetha pāmojja adhigaccheyya somanassa
translated: He would experience joy and happiness on that account.

original: Evameva kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu yathā iṇaṁ yathā rogaṁ yathā bandhanāgāraṁ yathā dāsabyaṁ yathā kantāraddhānamaggaṁ, evaṁ ime pañca nīvaraṇe appahīne attani samanupassati.
analyzed: evam eva kho mahā rāja bhikkhu yathā iṇam yathā rogam yathā bandhanāgāram yathā dāsabyam yathā kantāra dhāna magge evam ime pañca nīvaraṇe appahīne attani samanupassati
translated: So too, sire, a bhikkhu sees that these five hindrances are not abandoned in himself.

original: Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, yathā āṇaṇyaṁ yathā ārogyaṁ yathā bandhanāmokkhaṁ yathā bhujissaṁ yathā khemantabhūmiṁ;
analyzed: sā iyyathā api mahā rāja yathā āṇaṇyam yathā ārogyam yathā bandha nāmokkham yathā bhujissam yathā khemanta bhūmi
translated: Just as, sire, one sees freedom from debt, freedom from sickness, release from prison, prosperity, and a place of safety and freedom from danger,

original: evameva kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahīne attani samanupassati.
analyzed: evam eva kho mahā rāja bhikkhu ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahīne attani samanupassati
translated: In the same way, sire, a bhikkhu sees that these five hindrances have been abandoned in himself.

original: Tassime pañca nīvaraṇe pahīne attani samanupassato pāmojjaṁ jāyati, pamuditassa pīti jāyati, pītimanassa kāyo passambhati, passaddhakāyo sukhaṁ vedeti, sukhino cittaṁ samādhiyati.
analyzed: tassa ime pañca nīvaraṇe pahīne attani samanupassato pāmojjam jāyati pamuditassa pīti jāyati pīti manassa kāyo passambhati passaddha kāyo sukham vedeti sukhinaḥ cittam samādhiyati
translated: When he sees that these five hindrances have been abandoned in himself, joy arises in him. When he is joyful, rapture arises. When the mind is uplifted by rapture the body becomes tranquil. When the body is tranquil he feels bliss. And when he is blissful, his mind becomes concentrated.

original: 4.3.2.5. Paṭhamajhāna
analyzed: paṭhamajhāna
translated: .... First Meditation

original: So vivicceva kāmehi, vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: saḥ vivicca iva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi sa vitakkam sa vicāram viveka jam pīti sukham paṭhamam jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: Quite secluded from sensual desires, secluded from unwholesome states of mind, he enters upon and abides in the first meditation, which is accompanied by applied and sustained thought, with rapture and pleasure born of seclusion.

original: So imameva kāyaṁ vivekajena pītisukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa vivekajena pītisukhena apphuṭaṁ hoti.
analyzed: saḥ imam eva kāyam viveka jena pīti sukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati na assa kiñci sabbāvataḥ kāyassa viveka jena pīti sukhena apphuṭam hoti
translated: He pervades this very body with the rapture and pleasure born of seclusion, so that nothing of his entire body is unpervaded by rapture and pleasure born of seclusion.

original: Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, dakkho nhāpako vā nhāpakantevāsī vā kaṁsathāle nhānīyacuṇṇāni
analyzed: seyyathā api mahā rāja dakkhaḥ nhāpakaḥ vā nhāpaka antevāsī vā kasathāle nhānīya cuṇṇāni
translated: Just as if, sire, a skilled bath man or a bath man’s apprentice would knead soap powder in a metal dish,

original: ākiritvā udakena paripphosakaṁ paripphosakaṁ sanneyya, sāyaṁ nhānīyapiṇḍi snehānugatā
analyzed: ākiritvā udakena paripphosakam paripphosakam sanneyya sāyam nhānīya piṇḍi sneha anugatā
translated: and having covered it with water, he would sprinkle it again and again,🔽and in the evening the lump of bath powder would be saturated with moisture,

original: snehaparetā santarabāhirā phuṭā snehena, na ca paggharaṇī;🔽evameva kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṁ vivekajena pītisukhena abhisandeti parisandeti
analyzed: sneha paretā santara bāhirā phuṭā snehena na ca paggharaṇī  evam eva kho mahā rāja bhikkhu imam eva kāyam viveka jena pīti sukhena abhisandeti parisandeti
translated: and having sprinkled it all over, he would sprinkle it again and again, so that the whole ball of bath powder would be saturated with moisture, soaked through, as it were, and thoroughly drenched inside and out, yet no moisture would ooze out;

original: paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa vivekajena pītisukhena apphuṭaṁ hoti.
analyzed: paripūreti parippharati na assa kiñci sabbāvataḥ kāyassa viveka jena pīti sukhena apphuṭam hoti
translated: so too, a bhikkhu makes the rapture and pleasure born of seclusion drench, steep, fill, and pervade this body, so that there is no part of his whole body unpervaded by the rapture and pleasure born of seclusion.

original: Idampi kho, mahārāja, sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ purimehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmaññaphalehi abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
analyzed: idam api kho mahā rāja sandiṭṭhikam sāmañña phalam purimehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmañña phalehi abhikkantataram ca paṇītataram ca
translated: This, Prince, is another superhuman state, a distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones, a dwelling in comfort, which is rightly spoken by the Blessed One, who knows and sees, the Arahant, the Fully Enlightened One.

original: 4.3.2.6. Dutiyajhāna
analyzed: dutiya jhāna
translated: .... Second Jhana

original: Puna caparaṁ, mahārāja, bhikkhu vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā ajjhattaṁ sampasādanaṁ cetaso ekodibhāvaṁ avitakkaṁ avicāraṁ samādhijaṁ pītisukhaṁ dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: puna capara mahā rāja bhikkhu vitakka vicārānam vūpasamā ajjhattam sampasādanam cetasaḥ eka udi bhāvam a vitakkam a vicāram samādhi jam pīti sukham dutiyam jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: “Again, with the stilling of applied and sustained thought, a bhikkhu enters upon and abides in the second jhana, which has self-confidence and singleness of mind without applied and sustained thought, with rapture and pleasure born of concentration.

original: So imameva kāyaṁ samādhijena pītisukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa samādhijena pītisukhena apphuṭaṁ hoti.🔽Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, udakarahado gambhīro ubbhidodako tassa nevassa puratthimāya
analyzed: saḥ imam eva kāyam samādhi jena pīti sukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati na assa kiñci sabbāvataḥ kāyassa samādhi jena pīti sukhena apphuṭam hoti  seyyathā api mahā rāja udaka rahadaḥ gambhīraḥ ubbhida udako tassa na iva assa puratthimāya
translated: He pervades this very body with the happiness and joy born of concentration, so that there is no part of his whole body unpervaded by the happiness and joy born of concentration.

original: disāya udakassa āyamukhaṁ, na dakkhiṇāya disāya udakassa āyamukhaṁ, na pacchimāya
analyzed: disāya udakassa āya mukha na dakkhiṇāya disāya udakassa āya mukha na pacchimāya
translated: Just as if, Mahārāja, there were a deep lake in a mountain recess, clear, limpid, and undisturbed, so that a man with good eyesight standing on the bank could see shells, gravel, and pebbles, and also shoals of fish swimming about and resting.

original: disāya udakassa āyamukhaṁ, na uttarāya disāya udakassa āyamukhaṁ, devo ca na kālena
analyzed: disāya udakassa āyamukha na uttarāya disāya udakassa āyamukha devo ca na kālena
translated: He might think: ‘This deep lake is clear, limpid, and undisturbed, so that I can see shells, gravel, and pebbles, and also shoals of fish swimming about and resting.’

original: kālaṁ sammādhāraṁ anuppaveccheyya.
analyzed: kālam sammādhāram
translated: So too, a bhikkhu might think: ‘This mind of mine is not agitated…🔽Just as if, Mahārāja, there were a deep lake in a mountain recess, clear, limpid, and undisturbed, and a man with good eyesight standing on the bank could see shells, gravel, and pebbles, and also shoals of fish swimming about and resting.

original: Atha kho tamhāva udakarahadā sītā vāridhārā ubbhijjitvā tameva udakarahadaṁ sītena🔽vārinā abhisandeyya parisandeyya paripūreyya paripphareyya, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato🔽udakarahadassa sītena vārinā apphuṭaṁ assa.
analyzed: atha khalu udaka rahadā sītā vāri dhārāḥ ubbhijjitvā tam eva udaka rahadam sītena 🔽vārinā abhisandeyya parisandeyya paripūreyya paripphareyya na assa kiñci sabbāvataḥ 🔽udakarahadassa sītena vārinā apphuṭam assa
translated: Then a cool wind might blow over that lake, and the waves might subside, the water become still and smooth, and the surface mirror-like.🔽Then the man might think: ‘This deep lake is clear, limpid, and undisturbed, so that I can see shells, gravel, and pebbles, and also shoals of fish swimming about and resting.’

original: Evameva kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṁ samādhijena pītisukhena abhisandeti
analyzed: evam eva kho mahā rāja bhikkhu imam eva kāyam samādhi jena pīti sukhena abhisandeti
translated: In the same way, sire, a bhikkhu pervades this very body with a mind that is purified and bright,

original: parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa samādhijena pītisukhena apphuṭaṁ hoti.
analyzed: parisandeti paripūreti parippharati na assa kiñci sabbāvataḥ kāyassa samādhi jena pīti sukhena apphuṭam hoti
translated: radiant, cleansed, and made pure, so that there is no part of his whole body unpervaded by the mind that is purified and bright, radiant, cleansed, and made pure.

original: Idampi kho, mahārāja, sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ purimehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmaññaphalehi abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
analyzed: idam api kho mahā rāja sandiṭṭhikam sāmañña phalam purimehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmañña phalehi abhikkantataram ca paṇītataram ca
translated: This, sire, is another fruit of recluseship that is visible here and now, greater and more excellent than the previous ones.

original: 4.3.2.7. Tatiyajhāna🔽Puna caparaṁ, mahārāja, bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sato sampajāno,
analyzed: tatiyajhāna  puna capara mahā rāja bhikkhu pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sataḥ sampajāno
translated: .... The third jhāna

original: sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṁvedeti, yaṁ taṁ ariyā ācikkhanti: ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti,
analyzed: sukham ca kāyena paṭisavedeti yam tam ariyāḥ ācikkhanti upekkhakaḥ satimā sukha vihārī iti
translated: “And further, sire, with the fading away of happiness as well a bhikkhu dwells equanimous and, mindful and clearly comprehending, he experiences that happiness of which the Noble Ones say: ‘Happy is he who dwells equanimous and mindful,’

original: tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: tatiyam jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: he enters upon and abides in the third jhāna.

original: So imameva kāyaṁ nippītikena sukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa nippītikena sukhena apphuṭaṁ hoti.
analyzed: saḥ imam eva kāyam nippītikena sukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati na assa kiñci sabbāvataḥ kāyassa nippītikena sukhena apphuṭam hoti
translated: He pervades this very body with a mind that is purified and bright, radiant, cleansed, and made pure, so that there is no part of his whole body unpervaded by the mind that is purified and bright, radiant, cleansed, and made pure.

original: Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, uppaliniyaṁ vā paduminiyaṁ vā puṇḍarīkiniyaṁ vā appekaccāni
analyzed: seyyathā api mahā rāja uppaliniyam vā paduminiyam vā puṇḍarīkiniyam vā appekaccāni
translated: Just as in a lotus pond, sire, in which some of the lotuses

original: uppalāni vā padumāni vā puṇḍarīkāni vā udake jātāni udake saṁvaḍḍhāni udakānuggatāni🔽antonimuggaposīni, tāni yāva caggā yāva ca mūlā sītena vārinā abhisannāni parisannāni🔽paripūrāni paripphuṭāni, nāssa kiñci sabbāvataṁ uppalānaṁ vā padumānaṁ vā puṇḍarīkānaṁ
analyzed: uppalāni vā padumāni vā puṇḍarīkāni vā udake jātāni udake savaḍḍhāni udaka anuggatāni  antonimuggaposīni tāni yāva caggā yāva ca mūlā sītena vārinā abhisannāni parisannāni  paripūrāni paripphuṭāni na assa kiñci sabbāvatam uppalānam vā padumānam vā puṇḍarīkānam
translated: Just as in a pond full of blue or red or white lotuses, some of the lotuses that are born in the water, grow up in the water, without rising out of the water,

original: vā sītena vārinā apphuṭaṁ assa;
analyzed: vā sītena vārinā apphuṭam assa
translated: thrive in the water without being soiled by the water;🔽and some of them, though born in the water and grown up in the water, rise out of the water and stand untainted by the water;

original: evameva kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṁ nippītikena sukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa nippītikena sukhena apphuṭaṁ hoti.
analyzed: evam eva kho mahā rāja bhikkhu imam eva kāyam nippītikena sukhena abhisandeti parisandeti paripūreti parippharati na assa kiñci sabbāvataḥ kāyassa nippītikena sukhena apphuṭam hoti
translated: so too, a bhikkhu makes the rapture and pleasure born of concentration drench this body, steep it, fill it, and pervade it, so that there is no part of his whole body unpervaded by the rapture and pleasure born of concentration.

original: Idampi kho, mahārāja, sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ purimehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmaññaphalehi abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
analyzed: idam api kho mahā rāja sandiṭṭhikam sāmañña phalam purimehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmañña phalehi abhikkantataram ca paṇītataram ca
translated: This, Prince, is another superhuman state, a distinction in knowledge and vision worthy of the noble ones, a dwelling in comfort, which is noble and pertains to the higher mind, and which the Teacher or his disciple who is a teacher teaches for the purification of beings, for the overcoming of sorrow and lamentation, for the passing away of pain and displeasure, for the achievement of the method, for the realization of nibbāna.

original: 4.3.2.8. Catutthajhāna
translated: .... The fourth jhāna

original: Puna caparaṁ, mahārāja, bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā, pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ
analyzed: puna capara mahā rāja bhikkhu sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbā iva somanassa domanassāna
translated: “And further, the monk, having given up pleasure and given up pain, and with the disappearance of former gladness and sadness, enters and remains in the fourth jhāna which is beyond pleasure and pain, and purified by equanimity and mindfulness.

original: atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: atthaṅgamā adukkham asukham upekkhā sati pārisuddhim catuttham jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: “And further, with the abandoning of pleasure and pain, and with the previous disappearance of joy and grief, a bhikkhu enters upon and abides in the fourth jhana, which has neither-pain-nor-pleasure and purity of mindfulness due to equanimity.

original: So imameva kāyaṁ parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena pharitvā nisinno hoti, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena apphuṭaṁ hoti.
analyzed: saḥ imam eva kāyam parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena pharitvā nisinnaḥ hoti na assa kiñci sabbāvataḥ kāyassa parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena apphuṭam hoti
translated: “He sits pervading this body with pure bright mind so that there is no part of his whole body unpervaded by pure bright mind.

original: Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, puriso odātena vatthena sasīsaṁ pārupitvā nisinno assa, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa odātena vatthena apphuṭaṁ assa;
analyzed: seyyathā api mahā rāja purisaḥ odātena vatthena sa sīsam pārupitvā nisinnaḥ assa na assa kiñci sabbāvataḥ kāyassa odātena vatthena apphuṭam assa
translated: Just as though a man were sitting covered from the head down with a white cloth, so that there would be no part of his whole body not covered by the white cloth;

original: evameva kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu imameva kāyaṁ parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena pharitvā nisinno hoti, nāssa kiñci sabbāvato kāyassa parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena apphuṭaṁ hoti.
analyzed: evam eva kho mahā rāja bhikkhu imam eva kāyam parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena pharitvā nisinnaḥ hoti na assa kiñci sabbāvataḥ kāyassa parisuddhena cetasā pariyodātena apphuṭam hoti
translated: so too, a bhikkhu sits pervading this body with pure bright mind so that there is no part of his whole body unpervaded by pure bright mind.🔽“

original: Idampi kho, mahārāja, sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ purimehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmaññaphalehi abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
analyzed: idam api kho mahā rāja sandiṭṭhikam sāmañña phalam purimehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmañña phalehi abhikkantataram ca paṇītataram ca
translated: This fruit of recluseship is more excellent and sublime than the former fruits of recluseship.🔽... Eight knowledges

original: 4.3.3. Aṭṭhañāṇa🔽4.3.3.1. Vipassanāñāṇa
analyzed: aṭṭhañ āṇa  vipassanā ñāṇa
translated: ... Insight knowledge

original: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte ñāṇadassanāya cittaṁ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti.
analyzed: saḥ evam samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigata upakkilese mudu bhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñja ppatte ñāṇa dassanāya cittam abhinīharati abhininnāma iti
translated: When his concentrated mind was thus purified, bright, unblemished, free from defilements, malleable, wieldy, steady, and attained to imperturbability, he directed it to knowledge of the destruction of the taints.

original: So evaṁ pajānāti:🔽‘ayaṁ kho me kāyo rūpī cātumahābhūtiko mātāpettikasambhavo odanakummāsūpacayo aniccucchādanaparimaddanabhedanaviddhaṁsanadhammo;
analyzed: saḥ evam pajānāti  ayam kho me kāyaḥ rūpī cātumahābhūtikaḥ mātā pettika sambhavaḥ odana kummāsu upacayaḥ anicca chādana parimaddana bhedana viddhasana dhammo
translated: He understood as it really is:

original: idañca pana me viññāṇaṁ ettha sitaṁ ettha paṭibaddhan’ti.
analyzed: idam ca pana me viññāṇam ettha sitam ettha paṭibaddhanti
translated: ‘This is suffering’; ‘This is the origin of suffering’; ‘This is the cessation of suffering’; ‘This is the way leading to the cessation of suffering’; ‘These are the taints’; ‘This is the origin of the taints’; ‘This is the cessation of the taints’; ‘This is the way leading to the cessation of the taints.’🔽He knew:🔽‘These are the four noble truths.’

original: Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, maṇi veḷuriyo subho jātimā aṭṭhaṁso suparikammakato accho vippasanno anāvilo sabbākārasampanno.
analyzed: seyyathā api mahā rāja maṇi veḷuriyaḥ subhaḥ jātimā aṭṭhasas su parikamma kataḥ acchaḥ vippasannaḥ anāvilaḥ sabba ākāra sampannaḥ
translated: Just as if, Mahārāja, a man with good sight were to hold a clear, bright mirror in front of his face: he would see the image of his face in the mirror.🔽So too, Mahārāja, he understood as it really is: ‘This is suffering’; ‘This is the origin of suffering’; ‘This is the cessation of suffering’; ‘This is the way leading to the cessation of suffering.’

original: Tatrāssa suttaṁ āvutaṁ nīlaṁ vā pītaṁ vā lohitaṁ vā odātaṁ vā paṇḍusuttaṁ vā.
analyzed: tatra assa suttam āvutam nīlam vā pītam vā lohitam vā odātam vā paṇḍusuttam vā
translated: and a blue, yellow, red, white or brown thread had been fastened to it.

original: Tamenaṁ cakkhumā puriso hatthe karitvā paccavekkheyya:
analyzed: tam enam cakkhumā purisaḥ hatthe karitvā paccavekkheyya
translated: A man with good sight, taking it in his hand, would examine it thus:

original: ‘ayaṁ kho maṇi veḷuriyo subho jātimā aṭṭhaṁso suparikammakato accho vippasanno anāvilo sabbākārasampanno;🔽tatridaṁ suttaṁ āvutaṁ nīlaṁ vā pītaṁ vā lohitaṁ vā odātaṁ vā paṇḍusuttaṁ vā’ti.
analyzed: ayam kho maṇi veḷuriyaḥ subhaḥ jātimā aṭṭhasas su parikamma kato acchaḥ vippasannaḥ anāvilaḥ sabba ākāra sampanno  tatra idam suttam āvutam nīlam vā pītam vā lohitam vā odātam vā paṇḍusuttam vā ati
translated: ‘This is a gem, a cat’s eye, of pure water, eight-faceted, well cut, and this is the thread fastened to it.’🔽So too, prince, a bhikkhu…

original: Evameva kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe🔽vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte ñāṇadassanāya cittaṁ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti.
analyzed: evam eva kho mahā rāja bhikkhu evam samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte an aṅgaṇe  vigata upakkilese mudu bhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñja ppatte ñāṇa dassanāya cittam abhinīharati abhininnāma iti
translated: concentrates his mind…and attains to the imperturbable.

original: So evaṁ pajānāti:
analyzed: saḥ evam pajānāti
translated: He understands thus:

original: ‘ayaṁ kho me kāyo rūpī cātumahābhūtiko mātāpettikasambhavo odanakummāsūpacayo aniccucchādanaparimaddanabhedanaviddhaṁsanadhammo;
analyzed: ayam kho me kāyaḥ rūpī cātumahābhūtikaḥ mātā pettika sambhavaḥ odana kummāsu upacayaḥ anicca chādana parimaddana bhedana viddhasana dhammo
translated: ‘This my body is material, made up of the four great elements, pro-duced from mother and father, nourished with rice and gruel, subject to impermanence, rubbing, pressing, dissolution, and disintegration;🔽and this my mind is supported by it and enclosed in it.’

original: idañca pana me viññāṇaṁ ettha sitaṁ ettha paṭibaddhan’ti.
analyzed: idam ca pana me viññāṇam ettha sitam ettha paṭibaddhanti
translated: Translation: idañca pana me viññāṇaṃ ettha sitaṃ ettha paṭibaddhan’ti.

original: Idampi kho, mahārāja, sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ purimehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmaññaphalehi abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.🔽4.3.3.2. Manomayiddhiñāṇa
analyzed: idam api kho mahā rāja sandiṭṭhikam sāmañña phalam purimehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmañña phalehi abhikkantataram ca paṇītataram ca  manaḥ maya iddhi ñāṇa
translated: Idañhi te, mahārāja, sandiṭṭhikaṃ sāmaññaphalaṃ purimehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmaññaphalehi abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca. 🔽... The Divine Abidings

original: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte manomayaṁ kāyaṁ abhinimmānāya cittaṁ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti.
analyzed: saḥ evam samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigata upakkilese mudu bhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñja ppatte manaḥ mayam kāyam abhinimmānāya cittam abhinīharati abhininnāma iti
translated: When his concentrated mind was thus purified, bright, unblemished, rid of imperfection, malleable, wieldy, steady, and attained to imperturbability, he directed it to the knowledge of the destruction of the taints.

original: So imamhā kāyā aññaṁ kāyaṁ abhinimmināti rūpiṁ manomayaṁ sabbaṅgapaccaṅgiṁ ahīnindriyaṁ.🔽Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, puriso muñjamhā īsikaṁ pavāheyya.

original: Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, itthī vā puriso vā daharo yuvā maṇḍanajātiko ādāse vā parisuddhe
analyzed: sā iyyathā api mahā rāja itthī vā purisaḥ vā daharaḥ yuvā maṇḍana jātikaḥ ādāse vā parisuddhe
translated: Just as a woman or man, young, youthful, fond of ornaments, on viewing the reflection of her or his face in a clean bright mirror or in a basin of clear water, would know if there were a spot there, thinking ‘There is a spot,’ or would know if there were no spot there, thinking ‘There is no spot’;

original: pariyodāte acche vā udakapatte sakaṁ mukhanimittaṁ paccavekkhamāno sakaṇikaṁ vā ‘sakaṇikan’ti
analyzed: pariyodāte acche vā udaka patte sakam mukha nimittam paccavekkhamāno sa kaṇikam vā sa kaṇikam ti
translated: even so, with mind concentrated, purified, and bright, unblemished, free from defects, pliant, malleable, steady, and attained to imperturbability, a bhikkhu directs and inclines his mind to the knowledge of the destruction of the taints.

original: jāneyya, akaṇikaṁ vā ‘akaṇikan’ti jāneyya;
analyzed: jāneyya a kaṇikam vai a kaṇikam iti jāneyya
translated: He understands: ‘This is suffering’; he understands: ‘This is the origin of suffering’; he understands: ‘This is the cessation of suffering’; he understands: ‘This is the way leading to the cessation of suffering.’🔽He understands: ‘These are the taints’; he understands: ‘This is the origin of the taints’; he understands: ‘This is the cessation of the taints’; he understands: ‘This is the way leading to the cessation of the taints.’🔽 Translation: Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, itthī vā puriso vā daharo yuvā maṇḍanakajātiko ādāse vā parisuddhe pariyodāte acche vā udakapatte sakaṁ mukhanimittaṁ paccavekkhamāno sakaṇikaṁ vā ‘sakaṇikan’ti jāneyya, akaṇikaṁ vā ‘akaṇikan’ti jāneyya;

original: evameva kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe
analyzed: evam eva kho mahā rāja bhikkhu evam samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte an aṅgaṇe
translated: evameva kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe

original: vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte cetopariyañāṇāya cittaṁ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti.
analyzed: vigata upakkilese mudu bhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñja ppatte cetaḥ pariya ñāṇāya cittam abhinīharati abhininnāma iti
translated: vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte cetopariyañāṇāya cittaṁ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti |

original: So parasattānaṁ parapuggalānaṁ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāti—🔽sarāgaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘sarāgaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti,
analyzed: so para sattānam para puggalānam cetasā cetaḥ paricca pajānāti  sa rāgam vā cittam sa rāgam cittam iti pajānāti
translated: So parasattānaṁ parapuggalānaṁ cetasā ceto paricca pajānāti—🔽sarāgaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘sarāgaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti,🔽vītarāgaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘vītarāgaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti,🔽sadosaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘sadosaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti,

original: vītarāgaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘vītarāgaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti,🔽sadosaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘sadosaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti,🔽vītadosaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘vītadosaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti,
analyzed: vīta rāgam vā cittam vīta rāgam cittam iti pajānāti 🔽sa dosam vā cittam sa dosam cittam iti pajānāti 🔽vīta dosam vā cittam vīta dosam cittam iti pajānāti
translated: vītadosaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘vītadosaṁ cittan

original: samohaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘samohaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti,🔽vītamohaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘vītamohaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti,
analyzed: sa moham vā cittam sa moham cittam iti pajānāti  vīta moham vā cittam vīta moham cittam iti pajānāti
translated: he knows a mind affected by grief as affected by grief,🔽he knows a mind unaffected by grief as unaffected by grief,

original: saṅkhittaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘saṅkhittaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti,🔽vikkhittaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘vikkhittaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti,🔽mahaggataṁ vā cittaṁ ‘mahaggataṁ cittan’ti pajānāti,🔽amahaggataṁ vā cittaṁ ‘amahaggataṁ cittan’ti pajānāti,
analyzed: saṅkhittam vā cittam saṅkhittam cittam iti pajānāti  vikkhittam vā cittam vikkhittam cittam iti pajānāti  mahaggatam vā cittam mahaggatam cittam iti pajānāti  a mahaggatam vā cittam a mahaggatam cittam iti pajānāti
translated: He knows a mind affected by grief as affected by grief,🔽and a mind unaffected by grief as unaffected by grief.

original: sauttaraṁ vā cittaṁ ‘sauttaraṁ cittan’ti pajānāti,
analyzed: sauttaram vā cittam sauttaram cittam iti pajānāti
translated: He knows a contracted mind as contracted,🔽and a distracted mind as distracted.

original: anuttaraṁ vā cittaṁ ‘anuttaraṁ cittan’ti pajānāti,
analyzed: anuttaram vā cittam anuttaram cittam iti pajānāti
translated: He knows an exalted mind as exalted,🔽and an unexalted mind as unexalted.

original: samāhitaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘samāhitaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti,
analyzed: samāhitam vā cittam samāhitam cittam iti pajānāti
translated: He knows a surpassed mind as surpassed,🔽and an unsurpassed mind as unsurpassed.

original: asamāhitaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘asamāhitaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti,
analyzed: a samāhitam vā cittam a samāhitam cittam iti pajānāti
translated: He knows a concentrated mind as concentrated,🔽and an unconcentrated mind as unconcentrated.

original: vimuttaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘vimuttaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti,🔽avimuttaṁ vā cittaṁ ‘avimuttaṁ cittan’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: vimuttam vā cittam vimuttam cittam iti pajānāti 🔽a vimuttam vā cittam a vimuttam cittam iti pajānāti
translated: He knows a liberated mind as liberated,🔽and an unliberated mind as unliberated.

original: Idampi kho, mahārāja, sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ purimehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmaññaphalehi abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
analyzed: idam api kho mahā rāja sandiṭṭhikam sāmañña phalam purimehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmañña phalehi abhikkantataram ca paṇītataram ca
translated: This, great king, is another fruit of the contemplative life, visible here and now, more excellent than the former ones.

original: 4.3.3.6. Pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇa
analyzed: pubbenivāsa anussati ñāṇa
translated: ... Knowledge of the Recollections of Past Lives

original: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇāya cittaṁ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti.🔽So anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo tissopi🔽jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṁsampi jātiyo🔽cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi
analyzed: saḥ evam samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigata upakkilese mudu bhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñja ppatte pubbenivāsa anussati ñāṇāya cittam abhinīharati abhininnāmeti  so aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussarati seyyathida ekam pi jātim dve pi jātiyaḥ tissaḥ api  jātiyo catasso pi jātiyaḥ pañca api jātiyaḥ dasa api jātiyaḥ vīsampi jātiyaḥ tisampi jātiyaḥ  cattālīsam pi jātiyaḥ paññāsam pi jātiyaḥ jāti satam pi jāti sahassam pi jāti sata sahassam pi
translated: When his concentrated mind is purified, bright, unblemished, rid of imperfection, malleable, wieldy, steady, and attained to imperturbability, he directs it to knowledge of the recollection of past lives.🔽He recollects his manifold past lives, i.e., one birth, two five, ten fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand, many eons of cosmic contraction, many eons of cosmic expansion, many eons of cosmic contraction and expansion: ‘There I had such a name, belonged to such a clan, had such an appearance. Such was my food, such my sensitivity, such my experience of pleasure and pain, such the end of my life. Passing away from that state, I re-arose there. There too I had such a name, belonged to such a clan, had such an appearance. Such was my food, such my sensitivity, such my experience of pleasure and pain, such the end of my life. Passing away from that state, I re-arose here.’ Thus he remembers his manifold past lives in their modes and details.

original: anekepi saṁvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe, ‘amutrāsiṁ
analyzed: aneke api savaṭṭa kappe aneke api vivaṭṭa kappe aneke api savaṭṭa vivaṭṭa kappe amutra asi
translated: for many aeons of world-dissolution, for many aeons of world-evolution, for many aeons of world-dissolution and world-evolution, ‘There I was with such a name,🔽

original: evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto,
analyzed: eva nāmaḥ evaṃgotto eva vaṇṇo evam āhāro eva sukha dukkha paṭisavedī evam āyu pariyanto
translated: I was of such and such name, of such and such a clan, of such and such a caste, of such and such a food, of such and such an experience of pleasure and pain, of such and such a life-term;

original: so tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ; tatrāpāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī🔽evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ
analyzed: saḥ tatas cutaḥ amutra udapādi tatra apāsim eva nāmaḥ evaṃgottaḥ eva vaṇṇo evam āhāraḥ eva sukha dukkha ppaṭisavedī  evam āyu pariyantaḥ saḥ tatas cutaḥ idhu upapanno ti iti sa ākāram sa uddesam aneka vihita
translated: and passing away from there, I arose there. There I was of such and such a name, of such and such a clan, of such and such a caste, of such and such a food, of such and such an experience of pleasure and pain, of such and such a life-term;

original: pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati.🔽Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, puriso sakamhā gāmā aññaṁ gāmaṁ gaccheyya, tamhāpi gāmā aññaṁ🔽gāmaṁ gaccheyya. So tamhā gāmā sakaṁyeva gāmaṁ paccāgaccheyya. Tassa evamassa: ‘ahaṁ
analyzed: pubbenivāsam anussarati  sa iyyathā api mahā rāja purisaḥ sakamhā gāmā aññam gāmam gaccheyya tamhā api gāmā añña  gāmam gaccheyya saḥ tamhā gāmā sakayā iva gāmam paccāgaccheyya tassa evam assa aha
translated: and passing away from there, I arose here.’ Thus with their characteristics and with their details he recollects his various past lives.🔽Just as, महाराज, a man might go from his own village to another village, and from that village to yet another village, and from that village he might return to his own village. To him it might occur: ‘I went from my own village to that village, there I stood thus, sat thus, spoke thus, kept silent thus;

original: kho sakamhā gāmā amuṁ gāmaṁ agacchiṁ, tatra evaṁ aṭṭhāsiṁ, evaṁ nisīdiṁ, evaṁ abhāsiṁ,🔽evaṁ tuṇhī ahosiṁ, tamhāpi gāmā amuṁ gāmaṁ agacchiṁ, tatrāpi evaṁ aṭṭhāsiṁ, evaṁ
analyzed: kho sakamhā gāmā amum gāmam agacchi tatra evam aṭṭhāsi evam nisīdi evam abhāsi 🔽evam tuṇhī ahosi tamhā api gāmā amum gāmam agacchi tatra api evam eva
translated: from that village I went to that village, there I stood thus, sat thus, spoke thus, kept silent thus;🔽and from that village I have returned to my own village.’

original: nisīdiṁ, evaṁ abhāsiṁ, evaṁ tuṇhī ahosiṁ, somhi tamhā gāmā sakaṁyeva gāmaṁ paccāgato’ti.
analyzed: nisīdi evam abhāsi evam tuṇhī ahosi somhi tamhā gāmā sakayā iva gāmam paccāgato ti
translated: I sat down, I spoke, I remained silent, I went away from that village to my own village.’

original: Evameva kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe🔽vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇāya cittaṁ🔽abhinīharati abhininnāmeti.🔽So anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo tissopi🔽jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṁsampi jātiyo
analyzed: evam eva kho mahā rāja bhikkhu evam samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte an aṅgaṇe  vigata upakkilese mudu bhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñja ppatte pubbenivāsa anussati ñāṇāya citta  abhinīharati abhininnāma iti  so aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussarati seyyathida ekam pi jātim dve pi jātiyaḥ tissaḥ api  jātiyo catasso pi jātiyaḥ pañca api jātiyaḥ dasa api jātiyaḥ vīsampi jātiyaḥ tisampi jātiyaḥ
translated: “In the same way, Prince, when a bhikkhu’s mind is thus concentrated, purified, bright, unblemished, rid of defilement, flexible, malleable, steady, and attained to imperturbability, he directs it to knowledge of the recollection of past lives.

original: cattālīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi
analyzed: cattālīsam pi jātiyaḥ paññāsam pi jātiyaḥ jāti satam pi jāti sahassam pi jāti sata sahassam pi
translated: He recollects his manifold past lives, that is, one birth, two five, ten fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand, many eons of cosmic contraction, many eons of cosmic expansion, many eons of cosmic contraction and expansion: ‘There I had such a name, belonged to such a clan, had such an appearance. Such was my food, such my sensitivity to pleasure and pain, such the end of my life. Passing away from that state, I re-arose there. There too I had such a name, belonged to such a clan, had such an appearance. Such was my food, such my sensitivity to pleasure and pain, such the end of my life. Passing away from that state, I re-arose here.’ Thus he recollects his manifold past lives in their modes and details.🔽“Again, Prince, when a bhikkhu’s mind is thus concentrated, purified, bright, unblemished, rid of defilement, flexible, malleable, steady, and attained to imperturbability, he directs it to knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings.

original: anekepi saṁvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe, ‘amutrāsiṁ
analyzed: aneke api savaṭṭa kappe aneke api vivaṭṭa kappe aneke api savaṭṭa vivaṭṭa kappe amutra asi
translated: He sees—by means of the divine eye, purified and surpassing the human—beings passing away and re-appearing, and he discerns how they are inferior and superior, beautiful and ugly, fortunate and unfortunate in accordance with their kamma:

original: evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto,
analyzed: eva nāmaḥ evaṃgotto eva vaṇṇo evam āhāro eva sukha dukkha paṭisavedī evam āyu pariyanto
translated: I was of such-and-such name, of such-and-such clan, of such-and-such caste, of such-and-such food, of such-and-such experience of pleasure and pain, of such-and-such length of life.

original: so tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ; tatrāpāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī🔽evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ
analyzed: saḥ tatas cutaḥ amutra udapādi tatra apāsim eva nāmaḥ evaṃgottaḥ eva vaṇṇo evam āhāraḥ eva sukha dukkha ppaṭisavedī  evam āyu pariyantaḥ saḥ tatas cutaḥ idhu upapanno ti iti sa ākāram sa uddesam aneka vihita
translated: Passing away from there, I re-arose there. There too I was of such-and-such name, of such-and-such clan, of such-and-such caste, of such-and-such food, of such-and-such experience of pleasure and pain, of such-and-such length of life.

original: pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati.
analyzed: pubbenivāsam anussarati
translated: Passing away from there, I re-arose here.’ Thus with their aspects and particulars he recollects his manifold past lives.

original: Idampi kho, mahārāja, sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ purimehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmaññaphalehi abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.🔽4.3.3.7. Dibbacakkhuñāṇa🔽So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte sattānaṁ cutūpapātañāṇāya cittaṁ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti.🔽So dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne
analyzed: idam api kho mahā rāja sandiṭṭhikam sāmañña phalam purimehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmañña phalehi abhikkantataram ca paṇītataram ca 🔽dibba cakkhu ñāṇa 🔽saḥ evam samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigata upakkilese mudu bhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñja ppatte sattānam cutūpapāta ñāṇāya cittam abhinīharati abhininnāma iti 🔽so dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkanta mānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne
translated: This, great king, is a fruit of the contemplative life, visible here and now, more excellent than the previous fruits.

original: hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate, yathākammūpage satte pajānāti: ‘ime
analyzed: hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti ime
translated: low, high, beautiful, ugly, good destinations, bad destinations, he knows beings according to how they come: ‘These venerable ones of such a nature,

original: vata bhonto sattā kāyaduccaritena samannāgatā vacīduccaritena samannāgatā manoduccaritena
analyzed: vata bhonto sattā kāya duccaritena samannāgatāḥ vacī duccaritena samannāgatāḥ manaḥ duccaritena
translated: He understands how beings pass on according to their actions (like this):

original: samannāgatā ariyānaṁ upavādakā micchādiṭṭhikā micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā. Te kāyassa
analyzed: samannāgatāḥ ariyānam upavādakāḥ micchādiṭṭhikāḥ micchādiṭṭhi kamma samādānā te kāyassa
translated: ‘These worthy beings who were ill-conducted in body, speech, and mind, revilers of Noble Ones, wrong in their views, who undertook actions wrong in their view,

original: bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapannā. Ime vā pana bhonto🔽sattā kāyasucaritena samannāgatā vacīsucaritena samannāgatā manosucaritena samannāgatā
analyzed: bhedāḥ param maraṇāḥ apāyam duggatim vinipātam nirayam upapannāḥ ime vā pana bhontaḥ  sattā kāya su caritena samannāgatā vacī su caritena samannāgatā manaḥ su caritena samannāgatā
translated: after the break-up of the body, after death, have arisen in a bad destination, a bad place, a world below, hell.

original: ariyānaṁ anupavādakā sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṁ🔽maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapannā’ti. Iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena
analyzed: ariyānaṃ an upavādakā sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhi kamma samādānā te kāyassa bhedā para  maraṇā sugatim saggam lokam upapannā ati iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkanta mānusakena
translated: But these worthy beings who were well-conducted in body, speech, and mind, not revilers of Noble Ones, right in their views, who undertook actions right in their view,

original: satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate,
analyzed: satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate
translated: after the break-up of the body, after death, have arisen in a good destination, a heavenly world.’ Thus with his mind, which is purified and cleansed, and become sensitive, supple, workable, firm, and imperturbable, he directs and inclines it to the knowledge of the destruction of the pollutants.🔽He knows as it really is: ‘This is suffering’, he knows as it really is: ‘This is the origin of suffering’, he knows as it really is: ‘This is the cessation of suffering’, he knows as it really is: ‘This is the practice leading to the cessation of suffering’.🔽He knows as it really is: ‘These are the pollutants’, he knows as it really is: ‘This is the origin of the pollutants’, he knows as it really is: ‘This is the cessation of the pollutants’, he knows as it really is: ‘This is the practice leading to the cessation of the pollutants’.

original: yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
analyzed: yathā kammūpage satte pajānāti
translated: he knows beings passing away and arising.

original: Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, majjhe siṅghāṭake pāsādo. Tattha cakkhumā puriso ṭhito passeyya
analyzed: seyyathā api mahā rāja majjhe siṅghāṭake pāsādaḥ tattha cakkhumā puriso ṭhito passeyya
translated: Suppose, sire, there were a palace in the middle of a crossroads, and a man with good sight standing there saw

original: manusse gehaṁ pavisantepi nikkhamantepi rathikāyapi vīthiṁ sañcarante majjhe siṅghāṭake🔽nisinnepi. Tassa evamassa: ‘ete manussā gehaṁ pavisanti, ete nikkhamanti, ete rathikāya
analyzed: manusse geham pavisante api nikkhamante api rathikāya api vīthim sañcarante majjhe siṅghāṭake  nisinne pi tassa evam assa ete manussāḥ geham pavisanti ete nikkhamanti ete rathikāya
translated: men going to and fro along the road, and sitting or lying in the middle of the crossroads.

original: vīthiṁ sañcaranti, ete majjhe siṅghāṭake nisinnā’ti.🔽Evameva kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe
analyzed: vīthim sañcaranti ete majjhe siṅghāṭake  evam eva kho mahā rāja bhikkhu evam samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte an aṅgaṇe
translated: He might think: ‘These men are going in, these are going out, these are walking along the road, these are sitting in the middle of the crossroads.’

original: vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte sattānaṁ cutūpapātañāṇāya
analyzed: vigata upakkilese mudu bhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñja ppatte sattānam cutūpapāta ñāṇāya
translated: Even so, sire, a monk, with mind concentrated, purified and bright, unblemished, free from defects, pliant, malleable, steady and attained to imperturbability,

original: cittaṁ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti.
analyzed: cittam abhinīharati abhininnāma iti
translated: resolves upon the knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings.

original: So dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne
analyzed: so dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkanta mānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne
translated: With the divine eye, which is purified and surpasses the human, he sees beings passing away and arising:

original: hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate, yathākammūpage satte pajānāti: ‘ime
analyzed: hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti ime
translated: low, high, beautiful, ugly, good destinations, bad destinations, he knows beings according to how they come: ‘These venerable ones of such a view, of such an approach to practice, of such a view and practice, after the break-up of the body, after death, will be reborn in a good destination, in a heavenly world.🔽

original: vata bhonto sattā kāyaduccaritena samannāgatā vacīduccaritena samannāgatā manoduccaritena
analyzed: vata bhonto sattā kāya duccaritena samannāgatāḥ vacī duccaritena samannāgatāḥ manaḥ duccaritena
translated: He understands how beings pass on according to their actions (like this):

original: samannāgatā ariyānaṁ upavādakā micchādiṭṭhikā micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa
analyzed: samannāgatāḥ ariyānam upavādakāḥ micchādiṭṭhikāḥ micchādiṭṭhi kamma samādānā te kāyassa
translated: ‘These worthy beings who were ill-conducted in body, speech, and mind, revilers of Noble Ones, wrong in their views, who undertook actions wrong in their view,

original: bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapannā. Ime vā pana bhonto
analyzed: bhedāḥ param maraṇāḥ apāyam duggatim vinipātam nirayam upapannāḥ ime vā pana bhontaḥ
translated: after the break-up of the body, after death, have arisen in a bad destination, a bad destination, a lower realm, Niraya Hell.

original: sattā kāyasucaritena samannāgatā vacīsucaritena samannāgatā manosucaritena samannāgatā🔽ariyānaṁ anupavādakā sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā. Te kāyassa bhedā paraṁ🔽maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ lokaṁ upapannā’ti. Iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena
analyzed: sattā kāya su caritena samannāgatā vacī su caritena samannāgatā manaḥ su caritena samannāgatā  ariyānaṃ an upavādakā sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhi kamma samādānā te kāyassa bhedā para  maraṇā sugatim saggam lokam upapannā ati iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkanta mānusakena
translated: But these worthy beings who were well-conducted in body, speech, and mind, not revilers of Noble Ones, right in their views, who undertook actions right in their view,🔽after the break-up of the body, after death, have arisen in a good destination, a heavenly world.’ Thus with his mind, which is purified and cleansed, made to glow, firm, and unperturbed,🔽he directs and inclines his mind to the knowledge of the destruction of the pollutants.

original: satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate;
analyzed: satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate
translated: He knows as it really is: ‘This is suffering’, he knows as it really is: ‘This is the origin of suffering’, he knows as it really is: ‘This is the cessation of suffering’, he knows as it really is: ‘This is the practice leading to the cessation of suffering’.🔽He knows as it really is: ‘These are the pollutants’, he knows as it really is: ‘This is the origin of the pollutants’, he knows as it really is: ‘This is the cessation of the pollutants’, he knows as it really is: ‘This is the practice leading to the cessation of the pollutants’.

original: yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
analyzed: yathā kammūpage satte pajānāti
translated: he knows beings according to how they come into existence.

original: Idampi kho, mahārāja, sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ purimehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmaññaphalehi abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
analyzed: idam api kho mahā rāja sandiṭṭhikam sāmañña phalam purimehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmañña phalehi abhikkantataram ca paṇītataram ca
translated: This, great king, is another wonderful and marvellous quality of the Tathagata’s disciple who has destroyed the taints.

original: 4.3.3.8. Āsavakkhayañāṇa
analyzed: āsava kkhaya ñāṇa
translated: ... Knowledge of the destruction of the taints

original: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte āsavānaṁ khayañāṇāya cittaṁ abhinīharati abhininnāmeti.
analyzed: saḥ evam samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigata upakkilese mudu bhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñja ppatte āsavānam khaya ñāṇāya cittam abhinīharati abhininnāma iti
translated: When his concentrated mind is purified, bright, unblemished, rid of imperfection, malleable, wieldy, steady, and attained to imperturbability, he directs it to knowledge of the destruction of the taints.

original: So idaṁ dukkhanti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ayaṁ dukkhasamudayoti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti,
analyzed: saḥ idam dukkhan ti yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam dukkha samudayaḥ iti yathābhūtam pajānāti
translated: He understands as it really is: ‘This is suffering’; he understands as it really is: ‘This is the origin of suffering’;

original: ayaṁ dukkhanirodhoti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
analyzed: ayam dukkha nirodhaḥ iti yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā iti yathābhūtam pajānāti
translated: he understands as it really is: ‘This is the cessation of suffering’; he understands as it really is: ‘This is the way leading to the cessation of suffering.’🔽He understands as it really is: ‘These are the taints’; he understands as it really is: ‘This is the origin of the taints’;

original: Ime āsavāti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ayaṁ āsavasamudayoti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ayaṁ āsavanirodhoti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ayaṁ āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadāti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
analyzed: ime āsavā ati yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam āsava samudayaḥ iti yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam āsava nirodhaḥ iti yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam āsava nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ati yathābhūtam pajānāti
translated: he understands as it really is: ‘This is the cessation of the taints’; he understands as it really is: ‘This is the way leading to the cessation of the taints.’

original: Tassa evaṁ jānato evaṁ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, bhavāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, avijjāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati,
analyzed: tassa evam jānataḥ evam passataḥ kāma āsavā api cittam vimuccati bhava āsavā api cittam vimuccati avijjā āsavā api cittam vimuccati
translated: When he knows and sees thus, his mind is liberated from the taint of sensual desire, from the taint of being, and from the taint of ignorance.

original: vimuttasmiṁ ‘vimuttam’iti ñāṇaṁ hoti,
analyzed: vimuttasmin vimuttam iti ñāṇam hoti
translated: When it is liberated there comes the knowledge: ‘It is liberated.’

original: ‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: brahmacariya katam karaṇīya na aparam itthattāya ati pajānāti
translated: He understands: ‘Birth is destroyed, the holy life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no more coming to any state of being.’

original: Seyyathāpi, mahārāja, pabbatasaṅkhepe udakarahado accho vippasanno anāvilo. Tattha
analyzed: seyyathā api mahā rāja pabbata saṅkhepe udaka rahadaḥ acchaḥ vippasannaḥ anāvilaḥ tattha
translated: “Suppose, Mahārāja, there were a pond in a mountain recess, clear, limpid, and undisturbed,

original: cakkhumā puriso tīre ṭhito passeyya sippisambukampi sakkharakathalampi macchagumbampi
analyzed: cakkhumā purisaḥ tīre ṭhito passeyya sippi sambukam pi sakkharakathalam pi maccha gumbam pi
translated: so that a man with eyes could see shells, gravel, and pebbles, and also shoals of fish swimming about and resting.

original: carantampi tiṭṭhantampi. Tassa evamassa: ‘ayaṁ kho udakarahado accho vippasanno anāvilo.
analyzed: carantam pi tiṭṭhantam pi tassa evam assa ayam kho udaka rahadaḥ acchaḥ vippasannaḥ anāvilaḥ
translated: He might think: ‘This pond is clear, limpid, and undisturbed,

original: Tatrime sippisambukāpi sakkharakathalāpi macchagumbāpi carantipi tiṭṭhantipī’ti.
analyzed: tatra ime sippi sambukāḥ api sakkhara kathalāḥ api maccha gumbāḥ caranti pi tiṭṭhanti pi iti
translated: and there are these shells, gravel, and pebbles, and also these shoals of fish swimming about and resting.’

original: Evameva kho, mahārāja, bhikkhu evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe
analyzed: evam eva kho mahā rāja bhikkhu evam samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte an aṅgaṇe
translated: “So too, Mahārāja, when the mind is thus concentrated, purified, bright, unblemished, rid of defilement, malleable, wieldy, steady, and attained to imperturbability,

original: vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte āsavānaṁ khayañāṇāya cittaṁ
analyzed: vigata upakkilese mudu bhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñja ppatte āsavānam khaya ñāṇāya citta
translated: and having given up what’s obstructive, his mind is inwardly stilled, unified, and well-concentrated.

original: abhinīharati abhininnāmeti.🔽‘So idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti,
analyzed: abhinīharati abhininnāma iti  saḥ idam dukkhan ti yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam dukkha samudayaḥ iti yathābhūtam pajānāti
translated: He directs and inclines his mind to the knowledge of the ending of the effluents.🔽He understands as it really is: ‘This is suffering.’ He understands as it really is: ‘This is the origination of suffering.’🔽He understands as it really is: ‘This is the cessation of suffering.’ He understands as it really is:

original: ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti🔽yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
analyzed: ayam dukkha nirodho ti yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ati  yathābhūtam pajānāti
translated: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of suffering.’

original: ‘Ime āsavā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ āsavasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti,🔽‘ayaṁ āsavanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti
analyzed: ime āsavāḥ ti yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam āsava samudayaḥ iti yathābhūtam pajānāti  ayam āsava nirodha uti yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam āsava nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ati
translated: He understands as it really is: ‘These are the effluents.’ He understands as it really is: ‘This is the origination of the effluents.’🔽He understands as it really is: ‘This is the cessation of the effluents.’ He understands as it really is:

original: yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
analyzed: yathābhūtam pajānāti
translated: ‘This is the practice that leads to the cessation of the effluents.’

original: Tassa evaṁ jānato evaṁ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, bhavāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, avijjāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati,
analyzed: tassa evam jānataḥ evam passataḥ kāma āsavā api cittam vimuccati bhava āsavā api cittam vimuccati avijjā āsavā api cittam vimuccati
translated: When he knows and sees in this way, his mind is freed from the effluent of sensuality, from the effluent of becoming, and from the effluent of ignorance.

original: vimuttasmiṁ ‘vimuttam’iti ñāṇaṁ hoti,
analyzed: vimuttasmin vimuttam iti ñāṇam hoti
translated: When it is freed, he knows it is freed.

original: ‘khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: brahmacariya katam karaṇīya na aparam itthattāya ati pajānāti
translated: he knows: ‘Birth is destroyed, the holy life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no more coming to any state of being.’

original: Idaṁ kho, mahārāja, sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ purimehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmaññaphalehi abhikkantatarañca paṇītatarañca.
analyzed: idam kho mahā rāja sandiṭṭhikam sāmañña phalam purimehi sandiṭṭhikehi sāmañña phalehi abhikkantataram ca paṇītataram ca
translated: This, great king, is the fruit of the homeless life more excellent and sublime than the previous fruits of the homeless life.

original: Imasmā ca pana, mahārāja, sandiṭṭhikā sāmaññaphalā aññaṁ sandiṭṭhikaṁ sāmaññaphalaṁ uttaritaraṁ vā paṇītataraṁ vā natthī”ti.
analyzed: imasmai ca pana mahā rāja sandiṭṭhikā sāmañña phalā aññam sandiṭṭhikam sāmañña phalam uttaritaram vā paṇītataram vā natthi iti
translated: And, great king, there is no fruit of the homeless life higher or more sublime than this one.”

original: 5. Ajātasattuupāsakattapaṭivedanā
analyzed: ajāta sattu upāsaka tta paṭivedanā
translated: . Ajatasattu’s Declaration of Lay Followership

original: Evaṁ vutte, rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: evam vutte rājā māgadhaḥ ajātasattu vedehi puttaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: When this was said, King Ajatasattu of Magadha, the son of Lady Videhi, said to the Blessed One:

original: “abhikkantaṁ, bhante, abhikkantaṁ, bhante.🔽Seyyathāpi, bhante, nikkujjitaṁ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṁ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa
analyzed: abhikkanta bhante abhikkanta bhante  sā iyyathā api bhante nikkujjitam vā ukkujjeyya paṭicchannam vā vivareyya mūḷhassa
translated: “Magnificent, Master Gotama! Magnificent!

original: vā maggaṁ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṁ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti;
analyzed: vā maggam ācikkheyya andhakāre vā tela pajjotam dhāreyya cakkhumantaḥ rūpāni dakkhanti iti
translated: Just as if he were to place upright what was overturned, to reveal what was hidden, to show the way to one who was lost, or to carry a lamp into the dark so that those with eyes could see forms,🔽in the same way has Master Gotama—through many lines of reasoning—made the Dhamma clear.

original: evamevaṁ, bhante, bhagavatā anekapariyāyena dhammo pakāsito.
analyzed: evam eva bhante bhagavatā aneka pariyāyena dhammo pakāsito
translated: In the same way, the Buddha has revealed the Dhamma in many ways.

original: Esāhaṁ, bhante, bhagavantaṁ saraṇaṁ gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhusaṅghañca.🔽Upāsakaṁ maṁ bhagavā dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṁ saraṇaṁ gataṁ.
analyzed: esā aha bhante bhagavantam saraṇam gacchāmi dhammañca bhikkhu saṅghañca  upāsakam mam bhagavā dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇa upetam saraṇam gata
translated: I go for refuge to the Buddha, the Teaching, and the Sangha of monks.🔽Please accept me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.

original: Accayo maṁ, bhante, accagamā yathābālaṁ yathāmūḷhaṁ yathāakusalaṁ, yohaṁ pitaraṁ dhammikaṁ dhammarājānaṁ issariyakāraṇā jīvitā voropesiṁ.
analyzed: accayaḥ ma bhante accagamāḥ yathābālam yathāmūḍham yathā akusala yā uham pitaram dhammikam dhamma rājānam issariya kāraṇā jīvitā voropesi
translated: I have made a mistake, reverend Sir, in that I was so foolish, so confused, so unskillful as to deprive my father, the righteous King Mahāvijita, of his life.

original: Tassa me, bhante bhagavā, accayaṁ accayato paṭiggaṇhātu āyatiṁ saṁvarāyā”ti.
analyzed: tassa me bhante bhagavā accayam accayataḥ paṭiggaṇhātu āyatim savarāya ati
translated: Please accept this mistake from me as a mistake, so I can restrain myself in the future.”

original: “Taggha tvaṁ, mahārāja, accayo accagamā yathābālaṁ yathāmūḷhaṁ yathāakusalaṁ, yaṁ tvaṁ pitaraṁ dhammikaṁ dhammarājānaṁ jīvitā voropesi.
analyzed: tat ha tva mahā rāja accayaḥ accagamāḥ yathābālam yathāmūḍham yathā akusala yam tvam pitaram dhammikam dhamma rājānam jīvitā voropesi
translated: “Indeed, great king, you have made a mistake in that you were so foolish, so confused, so unskillful as to deprive your father, the righteous King Mahāvijita, of his life.

original: Yato ca kho tvaṁ, mahārāja, accayaṁ accayato disvā yathādhammaṁ paṭikarosi, taṁ te mayaṁ paṭiggaṇhāma.
analyzed: yatas ca kho tva mahā rāja accayam accayataḥ disvā yathādhammam paṭikarosi tam te mayam paṭiggaṇhāma
translated: But since you see your mistake as a mistake and make amends in accordance with the Dhamma, we accept your amends.

original: Vuddhihesā, mahārāja, ariyassa vinaye, yo accayaṁ accayato disvā yathādhammaṁ paṭikaroti, āyatiṁ saṁvaraṁ āpajjatī”ti.
analyzed: vuddhi hesā mahā rāja ariyassa vinaye yaḥ accayam accayataḥ disvā yathādhammam paṭikaroti āyatim savaram āpajjati iti
translated: This is the growth in the ariyan discipline, that one who has fallen into an offence sees it as it really is.

original: Evaṁ vutte, rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: evam vutte rājā māgadhaḥ ajātasattu vedehi puttaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: When this was said, King Ajatasattu of Magadha, the son of the Videhi queen, said to the Lord:

original: “handa ca dāni mayaṁ, bhante, gacchāma bahukiccā mayaṁ bahukaraṇīyā”ti.
analyzed: handa ca dāni maya bhante gacchāma bahu kiccā mayam bahu karaṇīyā ati
translated: “Now, Lord, we depart. We are busy and have much to do.”

original: “Yassadāni tvaṁ, mahārāja, kālaṁ maññasī”ti.
analyzed: yaḥ sadāni tva mahā rāja kālam maññasi iti
translated: “Now is the time, Great King, to do as you think fit.”

original: Atha kho rājā māgadho ajātasattu vedehiputto bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāyāsanā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā padakkhiṇaṁ katvā pakkāmi.
analyzed: atha kho rājā māgadhaḥ ajātasattu vedehiputto bhagavataḥ bhāsitam abhinanditvā anumoditvā uṭṭhāya āsanā bhagavantam abhivādetvā padakkhiṇam katvā pakkāmi
translated: Then King Ajatasattu of Magadha, the son of the Videhi queen, after delighting and rejoicing in the Lord’s words, rose from his seat, and after paying homage to the Lord, keeping him on his right, he departed.

original: Atha kho bhagavā acirapakkantassa rañño māgadhassa ajātasattussa vedehiputtassa bhikkhū āmantesi:🔽“khatāyaṁ, bhikkhave, rājā.
analyzed: atha kho bhagavā acirapakkantassa raññaḥ māgadhassa ajātasattussa vedehiputtassa bhikkhū āmantesi  khatāya bhikkhave rājā
translated: Then the Lord, not long after King Ajatasattu of Magadha, the son of the Videhi queen, had departed, addressed the bhikkhus thus:🔽“This King Ajatasattu of Magadha is lost, bhikkhus,

original: Upahatāyaṁ, bhikkhave, rājā.
analyzed: upahatāya bhikkhave rājā
translated: utterly lost,

original: Sacāyaṁ, bhikkhave, rājā pitaraṁ dhammikaṁ dhammarājānaṁ jīvitā na voropessatha, imasmiññeva āsane virajaṁ vītamalaṁ dhammacakkhuṁ uppajjissathā”ti.
analyzed: sacāya bhikkhave rājā pitaram dhammikam dhamma rājānam jīvitā na voropessatha imasmin ñeva āsane virajam vīta malam dhamma cakkhum uppajjissatha ati
translated: If he doesn’t kill his father, the righteous King Mahāvijita, right here on this very seat he will give rise to the stainless vision of the Truth.”
